revision.text:
[[File:OudryHyena.jpg|thumb|''Hyena'' (1739) by [[Jean-Baptiste Oudry]], Striped hyena battling two mastiffs]] [[File:Hyenadog.jpg|right|150px|thumb|Parchment by [[Oppian|Oppian of Apamea]]]] '''Hyena-baiting''' is a [[blood sport]] involving the [[animal-baiting|baiting]] of [[hyenas]].
==History== The [[striped hyena]] has historically been the most frequently used species. Hyenas can be challenging opponents for dogs, as their jaws are exceedingly powerful. A single bite from a hyena lasting a few seconds without holding on is sufficient to kill a large dog.<ref>''Sketches of Indian Field Sports: With Observations on the Animals; Also an Account of Some of the Customs of the Inhabitants; with a Description of the Art of Catching Serpents, as Practised by the Conjoors and Their Method of Curing Themselves when Bitten: with Remarks on Hydrophobia and Rabid Animals'' by [[Daniel Johnson (surgeon)|Daniel Johnson]], published by R. Jennings, 1827</ref> Hyenas apparently fight dogs by trying to cripple them by biting at their legs.<ref>''Elements of geology: including fossil botany and palaeontology. A popular treatise on the most interesting parts of the science. Designed for the use of schools and general readers'' By John Lee Comstock Published by Farmer, Brace & co., 1857 432 pages</ref>
The [[Qalandar (clan)|Qalandar]] and the Thori in southern [[Punjab region|Punjab]], [[Kandahar]] and [[Quetta]], catch striped hyenas in order to pit them against specially trained dogs. The hyenas are restrained with ropes in order to pull them away from the dogs if necessary.<ref name="Magic">{{cite web | url = http://www.nanzan-u.ac.jp/SHUBUNKEN/publications/afs/pdf/a1246.pdf | title = The Magicality of the Hyena: Beliefs and Practices in West and South Asia | publisher = Asian Folklore Studies, Volume 57, 1998: 331–344 | accessdate = 23 | date = June 2008 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080625072539/http://www.nanzan-u.ac.jp/SHUBUNKEN/publications/afs/pdf/a1246.pdf | archivedate = 2008-06-25 | df = }}</ref> In [[Balochistan (region)|Baluchistan]], captured hyenas sometimes had [[bridle]]s placed in their mouths in order to prevent them from injuring the dogs. This was done in order to train the dogs into not fearing the animal.<ref name="Magic" /> It is known that a [[Dogue de Bordeaux]] bitch named Megre was pitted against hyenas in 1895, though the exact species was not identified.<ref name="Dogue">{{cite web | url = http://www.bulldoginformation.com/evolution-of-the-bulldog.html | title = The Dogue de Bordeaux | publisher = The Bulldog Information Library | accessdate = 03 |date=August 2008}}</ref>
== See also == *[[Wolf-baiting]] *[[Jackal coursing]]

{{Infobox concert | | concert_name = If I Loved You:
Gentlemen Prefer Broadway | image = [[File:If I Loved You, Luminato Festival (2014).jpg|300px]] | image_caption = Promotional artwork for the program | artist = [[Rufus Wainwright]] | date = June 14, 2014 | venue = [[Sony Centre for the Performing Arts]] | type = Festival | album = | last_concert = | this_concert = | next_concert = }} '''''If I Loved You: Gentlemen Prefer Broadway — An Evening of Love Duets'''''{{Cite web|url=http://luminatofestival.com/festival/2014/if-i-loved-you|title=If I Loved You: Gentlemen Prefer Broadway — An Evening of Love Duets|publisher=[[Luminato]]|accessdate=April 8, 2014|year=2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140412125237/http://www.luminatofestival.com/festival/2014/if-i-loved-you|archivedate=April 12, 2014|df=}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/arts/luminato-fest-taps-boy-george-isabella-rossellini-1.2602872||title=Luminato Fest taps Boy George, Isabella Rossellini|date=April 8, 2014|accessdate=April 8, 2014|publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]}} is a show conceived and directed by American-Canadian singer-songwriter [[Rufus Wainwright]], which premiered on June 14, 2014 during [[Luminato]] in [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada. The concert featured men singing classic love songs to one another, and included a full orchestra and performances by Wainwright and special guests [[Boy George]], [[David Byrne]], [[Josh Groban]] and [[Steven Page]]. Countertenor Brennan Hall, [[Brent Carver]], [[Glen Hansard]], [[Ezra Koenig]] and [[Andrew Rannells]] also appeared. The program featured songs written by gay men, including [[Noël Coward]], [[Lorenz Hart]], [[Jerry Herman]] and [[Cole Porter]]. ==Background and development== [[File:Rufus Wainright boyfriend Jorn Weisbrodt Shankbone.jpg|thumb|left|[[Rufus Wainwright]] and his husband Jörn Weisbrodt, who also serves as [[artistic director]] of [[Luminato]], in 2010.]] In 2012, having been together for seven years,{{Cite web|url=http://www.fuse.tv/videos/2012/10/acl-2012-rufus-wainwright-wedding-sean-lennon-mark-ronson-video-interview|title= ACL FEST 2012: RUFUS WAINWRIGHT CHATS RECENT WEDDING & WORKING WITH MARK RONSON|first=Araceli|last=Cruz|date=October 14, 2012|accessdate=May 2, 2014|publisher=Fuse}} Wainwright married Jörn Weisbrodt,{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2193220/Rufus-Wainwright-weds-Jorn-Weisbrodt-years---transgender-artist-conducts-ceremony.html|title=Raise your glasses! Rufus Wainwright weds Jorn Weisbrodt after five years together ... as transgender artist conducts ceremony|first=Nadia|last=Mendoza|work=[[Daily Mail]]|publisher=[[DMG Media]]|date=August 24, 2012|accessdate=April 9, 2014}}{{Cite journal|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/rufus-wainwright-weds-jorn-weisbrodt-20120824|title=Rufus Wainwright Weds Jorn Weisbrodt|accessdate=April 9, 2014|date=August 24, 2012|work=[[Rolling Stone]]}} who became [[artistic director]] of [[Luminato]] in 2011.{{Cite news|url=http://arts.nationalpost.com/2011/09/22/meet-luminatos-new-artistic-director/|title= Meet Luminato’s new artistic director|first=Melissa|last=Leong|accessdate=April 10, 2014|date=September 22, 2011|work=National Post}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/2011/09/22/luminato_hires_jorn_weisbrodt.html|title= Luminato hires Jorn Weisbrodt|date=September 22, 2011|accessdate=April 10, 2014|work=Toronto Star|first=Martin|last=Knelman}} Wainwright began appearing at Luminato in 2010, when he performed in support of his album ''[[All Days Are Nights: Songs for Lulu]]'' (2010) and presented the North American premiere of his first opera, ''[[Prima Donna (opera)|Prima Donna]]'' (2009).{{Cite web|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/toronto/article/LUMINATO-to-Present-IF-I-LOVED-YOU-Gentlemen-Prefer-Broadway-An-Evening-Of-Love-Duets-20140408#|title=Luminato to Present If I Loved You, Gentlemen Prefer Broadway: An Evening of Love Duets|date=April 8, 2014|publisher=Broadway World|accessdate=April 9, 2014|first=Alan|last=Henry}} Since then, Wainwright has performed at Luminato regularly. In 2012, he and his sister [[Martha Wainwright]] paid tribute to their mother ([[Kate McGarrigle]]), who died in 2010, with a program called ''Love Over and Over''.{{Cite news|url=http://www.postcity.com/Eat-Shop-Do/Do/March-2012/Rufus-Wainright-Knaan-and-Einstein-included-in-Luminato-line-up/|title= Rufus Wainwright, K'naan and Einstein included in Luminato line up|first=Bianca|last=Puorto|accessdate=April 10, 2014|date=March 14, 2012|publisher=[[Post City Magazines]]}} In 2014, Weisbrodt said of his association with both Luminato and Wainwright, "I think the primary purpose of my job is to love artists. Of course the relationship with my husband Rufus Wainwright is special but I feel if someone is more talented and deserves more to be associated with this festival it is him rather than me." For the 2014 festival, Wainwright conceived, created and directed a program called ''If I Loved You: Gentlemen Prefer Broadway'', which will feature "guys singing classic love songs to other guys".{{Cite news|url=http://www.citynews.ca/2014/04/09/boy-george-isabella-rossellini-to-perform-at-torontos-luminato-arts-festival/|title=Boy George, Isabella Rossellini to perform at Toronto’s Luminato arts festival|first=Erin|last=Criger|accessdate=April 9, 2014|date=April 9, 2014|work=[[CityNews]]|location=Toronto, Ontario}} ==Description and promotion== [[File:Sony CentreforthePerformingArts.jpg|thumb|right|Toronto's [[Sony Centre for the Performing Arts]] in 2010]] The [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] described the program as "male singers putting a new spin on dozens of love songs traditionally performed by a man and a woman, or by a man singing about a woman". It premiered on June 14, 2014 at the [[Sony Centre for the Performing Arts]], during Luminato's closing weekend, and was billed as a "prelude" to Toronto's [[WorldPride]] event, which took place during June 20–29 and replaced annual [[Pride Week (Toronto)|Pride Week]] events for the year. WorldPride also serves a concert partner.{{Cite web|url=http://www.worldpridetoronto.com/news/luminato-festival-presents-a-special-one-night-only-performance-in-celebration-of-worldpride-2014-toronto|title=Luminato Festival presents a special one-night only performance in celebration of WorldPride 2014 Toronto|date=April 8, 2014|accessdate=April 8, 2014|publisher=WorldPride Toronto}} The concert was officially confirmed on April 8, 2014 by Weisbrodt during a news conference about the festival. Wainwright and Weisbrodt had previously announced the show during an exclusive party they hosted. In promoting the concert, Weisbrodt said: {{Quote|text=What Rufus has put together for this evening of celebrating love is simply mind- boggling and something I would not have been able to pull off as the artistic director by myself. It promises to be one of the most unusual nights of music. Who doesn't want to hear these artists sing together? ''If I Loved You'' is not about turning something from "straight" to "gay," by singing love duets with only men, but instead, to declare the universality of love, and to celebrate love that comes in every shade.}} Luminato promoted the event with the following description: {{Quote|text=Rufus Wainwright teams with Grammy and Tony-winning music director Stephen Oremus to redefine dozens of the most beloved gems in the Great American Songbook, all love songs from Broadway musicals. Wainwright’s recontextualizations, performed exclusively by men and to men, fortify the songs’ universality as expressions of love. The groundbreaking evening will showcase Wainwright and an international spectrum of pop, jazz and musical theatre stars in unexpected, entirely enchanting pairs.}} In a press release also issued on April 8, a spokesperson for WorldPride said, "You can never underestimate the power of seeing yourself reflected in art, and how important that is to a feeling of belonging. WorldPride 2014 Toronto will showcase a rich range of LGBTQ art and voices from across the world in a once-in-a-lifetime event. We are delighted to partner with a cultural icon like the Luminato Festival to celebrate Toronto’s vibrant arts community and bring focus on global LGBTQ struggles and triumphs." Tickets went on sale the week of news conference. [[Boy George]]'s participation was confirmed on his official website, which also noted that the concert would take place on his birthday.{{Cite web|url=http://www.boygeorgeuk.com/wordpress/luminato-festival-special-guest/|title=Luminato Festival – Special Guest|accessdate=April 9, 2014|publisher=BoyGeorgeUK.com|year=2014}} ==Program== {{multiple image | align = right | direction = horizontal | width = | image1 = Boy George Here and Now Tour 2011 452 v3.jpg | width1 = {{#expr: (140 * 749 / 1000) round 0}} | alt1 = | caption1 = [[Boy George]] | image2 = David Byrne 2006.jpg | width2 = {{#expr: (140 * 591 / 698) round 0}} | alt2 = | caption2 = [[David Byrne]] | image3 = Josh Groban (Cropped).jpg | width3 = {{#expr: (140 * 313 / 419) round 0}} | alt3 = | caption3 = [[Josh Groban]] | image4 = StevenPageMassey.jpg | width4 = {{#expr: (140 * 400 / 450) round 0}} | alt4 = | caption4 = [[Steven Page]] }} The show included a full Broadway orchestra, [[Conducting|conducted]] by music director [[Stephen Oremus]], and performances by Wainwright and special guests Boy George, [[David Byrne]], [[Josh Groban]] and [[Steven Page]].{{cite news|last=Knelman|first=Martin|title=In Luminato world premiere, men sing love songs to men|url=https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/2014/04/08/in_luminato_world_premiere_men_sing_love_songs_to_men.html|accessdate=April 9, 2014|newspaper=[[Toronto Star]]|publisher=[[Star Media Group]]|date=April 8, 2014}} Also scheduled to appear are counter-tenor Brennan Hall, [[Brent Carver]], [[Glen Hansard]], [[Ezra Koenig]] and [[Andrew Rannells]]. Some of the songs were written by gay men, including [[Noël Coward]], [[Lorenz Hart]], [[Jerry Herman]] and [[Cole Porter]]. Included were the songs "[[If I Loved You]]" from ''[[Carousel (musical)|Carousel]]'' (1945), "Some Enchanted Evening" from ''[[South Pacific (musical)|South Pacific]]'' (1949), and "[[We Kiss in a Shadow]]" from ''[[The King and I]]'' (1951), all written by [[Rodgers and Hammerstein]], as well as songs by [[Stephen Sondheim]]. ==Reception== Prior to the concert, the ''Toronto Star'' said, "One thing we can be sure of is that, to borrow a phrase from one famous song, this could be the start of something big... After its Toronto premiere, it’s safe to assume ''If I Loved You'' will head for New York, the Hollywood Bowl and London". The paper's entertainment contributor Martin Knelman predicted that the concert would sell out "in record time". ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{YouTube|id= r6ikFeKTjlU|title=Rufus Wainwright's 'If I loved you'}} {{Rufus Wainwright}} {{Portal bar|LGBT|Music of Canada|Toronto}} [[Category:2014 in Canadian music]] [[Category:2014 in LGBT history]] [[Category:Concerts]] [[Category:LGBT culture in Toronto]] [[Category:LGBT events in Canada]] [[Category:LGBT-related music in Canada]] [[Category:LGBT-related music events]] [[Category:Rufus Wainwright]]

revision.comment: Rescued 1 archive link; reformat 1 link. [[User:Green Cardamom/WaybackMedic_2.1|Wayback Medic 2.1]]

{{Infobox graphic novel| title= Lucky Luke# 35
Jesse James |englishtitle= |foreigntitle= |image= JesseJamesLuckyLukecomic.jpg |caption=Cover of the English edition |publisher=[[Dargaud]] |date= |series=''[[Lucky Luke]]'' |origlanguage=French |origpublication=''[[Pilote]]'' magazine |origissues= |origdate= |origisbn= |transtitle= |transpublisher= |transdate= |transseriestitle= |transisbn= |translator= |writers=[[Goscinny]]
[[Morris (comics)|Morris]] |artists= Morris |colorists= |previssue= ''[[Dalton City (Lucky Luke)|Dalton City]]'' (1969) |nextissue= ''[[Western Circus (Lucky Luke)|Western Circus]]'' (1970) }} '''''Jesse James''''' is a [[Lucky Luke]] comic written by [[Goscinny]] and illustrated by [[Morris (comics)|Morris]]. The original French edition was printed in 1969 by [[Dargaud]]. English editions of this French series have been published by [[Dargaud]], Cinebook. Brockhampton Press and Tara Press. It is based on the true story of [[Jesse James]] (1847–1882). ==Plot== In 1880, the story begins with [[Jesse James]], who idolizes and tries to emulate [[Robin Hood]], but somehow he is not able to clearly define the line between the rich he is supposed to rob and the poor he is supposed to help. With the help of his [[Shakespeare]] aficionado brother [[Frank James|Frank]], he therefore simply redefines the term "poor" for his own benefit, and along with [[Cole Younger]] the two begin robbing trains en masse, forcing Lucky Luke to move out and stop them with the somewhat inept assistance of two [[Pinkerton National Detective Agency|Pinkerton detectives]]. ==See also== * [[Jesse James]] ==Notes== * [http://www.bdoubliees.com/journalspirou/auteurs4/morris.htm Morris publications in ''Spirou''] BDoubliées {{fr_icon}} ==External links== * [http://www.lucky-luke.com Lucky Luke official site album index] {{fr_icon}} * [https://archive.is/20121205060428/http://www.librairiegoscinny.com/spip.php?article49 Goscinny website on Lucky Luke]{{fr_icon}} {{Lucky Luke by Morris}} {{Jesse James}} [[Category:Comics by Morris]] [[Category:Lucky Luke albums]] [[Category:1969 in comics]] [[Category:Works originally published in Spirou (magazine)]] [[Category:Works by René Goscinny]] [[Category:Works about Jesse James]] [[Category:1880 in fiction]] [[Category:Comics based on real people]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Jesse James]] {{FrancoBelgian-comics-stub}}

{{Use British English|date=July 2011}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2011}} '''Ken Ring''' is a writer from [[Auckland]], New Zealand, who asserts that he can use lunar cycles to predict weather and earthquakes. He terms his predictions "alternative weather" and has authored books about the weather and climate. Ring publishes almanacs each year for New Zealand, Australia and Ireland in which he provides weather predictions for the entire year. His New Zealand almanac covers 64 towns.<ref name = "Lang"/> Ring's methods are unscientific and have been widely criticised as fake and pseudoscience by many scientists in the fields of meteorology and geology.<ref name = Keir/><ref name=twsJunS11>{{cite news |author= Agence France-Presse |title= Scientists slam ‘Moonman’ earthquake predictor |work= physorg.com |date= 3 March 2011 |url= http://www.physorg.com/news/2011-03-scientists-slam-moonman-earthquake-predictor.html|accessdate= 5 September 2011}}</ref>
Ring says he predicted the [[2010 Christchurch earthquake|4 September 2010 Christchurch earthquake]] and the deadly [[February 2011 Christchurch earthquake|22 February 2011 Christchurch earthquake]].<ref name = "tweet"/> He also said there would probably be an earthquake in Marlborough or north Canterbury "just before noon" on 20 March 2011.<ref name=Ring_March2011/> This caused some residents to leave Christchurch and led to criticism from scientists and sceptics.<ref name = "Smith"/> Further research into his predictions showed that his forecasting record did not hold up under scrutiny.<ref name=SillyBeliefs01>{{cite news |author= John at SillyBeliefs.com |title= Ken Ring did NOT predict the Sept Christchurch earthquake |work= sillybeliefs.com |date= 23 Feb 2011 |url= http://www.sillybeliefs.com/ring-rc-3.html#commentring-1|accessdate= 22 October 2014}}</ref>
==Mathman==
Ken Ring has been a mathematics teacher,<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.randomhouse.com.au/Author/Ring,%20Ken |title=Our authors: Ken Ring |work=Random House Australia |accessdate=20 June 2011}}</ref> musician, actor, clown, speech therapist, private tutor to children with learning difficulties, teacher of English as a second language, and part-time teacher's college lecturer.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mathman.co.nz/author.html |title=Author |work=Mathman.co.nz |publisher=Ken Ring |accessdate=27 February 2011}}</ref> He has used magic to teach children about mathematics, performing under the name "Mathman",<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mathman.co.nz/ |title=Ken Ring - home page |work=Mathman.co.nz |publisher=Ken Ring |accessdate=27 February 2011}}</ref> and has written books on mathematics, magic, teaching and music.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mathman.co.nz/books.html |title=Books/videos |work=Mathman.co.nz |publisher=Ken Ring |accessdate=27 February 2011}}</ref> He also co-wrote a book on reading cats' paws, which he says was a joke.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.readfearn.com/2011/01/a-sunrise-climate-cock-up-and-reading-cats-paws/ |title=A Sunrise climate cock-up and reading cat’s paws |first=Graham |last=Readfearn |date=6 January 2011 |work=Graham Readfearn |accessdate=19 June 2011}}</ref>
== Predicting weather ==
Ring is known for attempting to predict weather and authors books on "how the moon affects the weather", which include an almanac each year for New Zealand (since 1999), Australia (since 2006) and Ireland (since 2010).<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.smh.com.au/news/national/blame-it-on-the-moon-says-longrange-forecaster/2006/07/23/1153593211117.html |title=Blame it on the moon, says long-range forecaster |newspaper=Sydney Morning Herald |author=Richard Macey |date=24 July 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Kiwi weatherman offers ray of summer sunshine |url= http://www.independent.ie/farming/news-features/kiwi-weatherman-offers-ray-of-summer-sunshine-2043447.html |author=Martin Ryan |work=Independent.ie |date=2 February 2010}}</ref> He believes that the cycle of weather follows a lunar pattern and can be used to predict weather many years in advance.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.predictweather.co.nz/Default.aspx |title=The home of long range weather |work=Predict Weather |accessdate=27 March 2011}}</ref> The [[Lunar precession|lunar cycle]] occurs every 9 years,<ref>{{cite encyclopedia |title=Lunar Markings on Fajada Butte, Chaco Canyon, New Mexico |author=A. Sofaer, R. M. Sinclair and L. E. Doggett |editor=A.F. Aveni |pages=169–86 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=1982 |url= http://www.solsticeproject.org/lunarmark.htm |encyclopedia= Archaeoastronomy in the New World}}</ref> while the [[solar cycle]] repeats at 11 year intervals<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Friis-Christensen | first1 = E. | last2 = Lassen | first2 = K. | title = Length of the Solar Cycle: An Indicator of Solar Activity Closely Associated with Climate | journal = Science | volume = 254 | issue = 5032 | pages = 698–700 | year = 1991 | pmid = 17774798 | doi = 10.1126/science.254.5032.698|bibcode = 1991Sci...254..698F }}</ref> and by assessing the two Ring believes that the weather recycles through a 355-day cycle, a 19-year cycle, and a 36-year cycle.<ref name = "Lang">{{cite news |title=Thinking outside the square |author=Sarah Lang |date=23 June 2008 |newspaper=New Zealand Herald |url= http://www.nzherald.co.nz/lifestyle/news/article.cfm?c_id=6&objectid=10517894}}</ref> According to his website it is not an exact science - it's not scientific at all{{original research inline|date=November 2014}} - and is opinion-based similar to economics or political science or astrology and his rainfall predictions can be out by 24 hours and a radius of {{convert|50|to|60|mi|km}}.<ref name=ring194>{{cite web |author=Ken Ring |url= http://predictweather.co.nz/ArticleShow.aspx?ID=194&type=home |title=An inexact science |work=Predict Weather |date=1 October 2009 |accessdate=27 March 2011}}</ref>
His New Zealand almanac covers 64 towns.<ref name = "Lang"/> He also writes columns for farming and fishing publications and is an on-call weather reporter for [[Seven Network|Channel 7]]'s [[Today Tonight]] show.<ref name = "Lang"/> He says he has provided forecasts for specific events including the [[Melbourne Cup]], [[Ellerslie Flower Show]] and the Auckland Santa Parade.<ref name ="Kiong">{{cite news|title=Moon man offers forecasts to help selectors |author=Errol Kiong |date=6 September 2007|newspaper=New Zealand Herald|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/rugby/news/article.cfm?c_id=80&objectid=10461924}}</ref> Ring speaks at various business and media events and has produced long range weather predictions for the [[Gisborne City Council]] through to 2020.<ref name = "Lang"/>
He terms his predictions "alternative weather"<ref>{{cite news |title=Weather with a jazz beat |author=Anna Rushworth and Anna Leask |date=21 September 2008 |newspaper=New Zealand Herald |url= http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10533362}}</ref> and they are not supported by real science.<ref name=ring195>{{cite web |url=http://www.predictweather.co.nz/ArticleShow.aspx?ID=195&type=home |title=Ken Ring, the Moonman, and lunar science |work=Predict Weather |date=12 August 2010 |accessdate=27 March 2011}}</ref> Author of the New Zealand Weather Book and [[MetService]] employee Erick Brenstrum, wrote a column in the [[New Zealand Geographic]] analysing his 2005 predictions. He compared two weather systems (the northwest winds that bring rain to the west coast and lows that bring rain to the east coast) and has stated that out of 40 occurrences only 1 matched with Ring's predictions.<ref name = "Renowden">{{cite web |url= http://www.limestonehills.co.nz/Down%20On%20The%20Farm/Topics/Ringworld.html |title=On The Farm Truffles & Stuff: Ringworld |publisher=Gareth Renowden |author=Gareth Renowden |date=19 September 2006 |accessdate=27 March 2011}}</ref> Ken replied accusing Brenstrum of bullying and insists he has proof of an 85 percent success rate, to which the editor responded with: "...once you publish a book, you're fair game for public scrutiny of its content and your own competence."<ref name = "Renowden"/><!---if someone has access to these articles it would make a much better reference than this---> Retired schoolteacher and amateur astronomer Bill Keir believes Ring makes a genuine attempt at scientific discourse, but doesn't understand the science or changes it to fit with his own theories.<ref name = "Lang"/> Keir published articles in the [[Auckland Astronomical Society]] journal that examine and critique Ring's theories.<ref name=Keir>{{cite web|title=Does the Moon Cause the River (part 1) |author=Bill Keir |publisher=Auckland Astronomical Society |url=//www.astronomy.org.nz/aas/Journal/Oct2004/PseudoWeather.asp |accessdate=28 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071012030258/http://www.astronomy.org.nz/aas/Journal/Oct2004/PseudoWeather.asp |archivedate=12 October 2007 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Does the Moon Cause the River (part 2) |author=Bill Keir |publisher=Auckland Astronomical Society |url=//www.astronomy.org.nz/aas/Journal/Nov2004/PseudoWeather.asp |accessdate=28 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071012095338/http://www.astronomy.org.nz/aas/Journal/Nov2004/PseudoWeather.asp |archivedate=12 October 2007 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Does the Moon Cause the River (part 3) |author=Bill Keir |publisher=Auckland Astronomical Society |url=//www.astronomy.org.nz/aas/Journal/Apr2005/PseudoWeather.asp |accessdate=28 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071012064210/http://www.astronomy.org.nz/aas/Journal/Apr2005/PseudoWeather.asp |archivedate=12 October 2007 |df= }}</ref>
Ring says that a former client and member of the [[All Blacks]] management approached him in 2007 for forecasts on days when the team was playing, reportedly to aid in team selections.<ref name ="Kiong"/> [[Ian Ferguson (canoeist)|Ian Ferguson]], a former Olympian and now an [[Event planning|events organiser]] says he consults with Ring before any big event and has never had to cancel.<ref>{{cite news |title=Running rings around the Moon |author=Steve Mason |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/marlborough-express/news/editors-blog/4783257/Running-rings-around-the-Moon |date=18 March 2011 |newspaper=The Marlborough Express}}</ref> Ring uses similar methods (moons position and phase) to predict when fish will bite, publishing his predictions in the NZ Fishing World magazine.<ref>{{cite web |author=Geoff Thomas |url= http://www.nzherald.co.nz/opinion/news/article.cfm?c_id=466&objectid=10715245 |title=Moon Man right on the spot |work=New Zealand Herald |date=27 March 2011 |accessdate=27 March 2011}}</ref> Ring denies [[global warming]], stating that it is a "{{Sic|hide=y|politically|-}}motivated power grab by politicians and the far left" and "full of bad science".<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.predictweather.co.nz/ArticleShow.aspx?ID=219&type=home |title=Imagine no global warming, it's easy if you try.. |work=Predict Weather |date=2 October 2009 |accessdate=27 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.predictweather.co.nz/ArticleShow.aspx?ID=243&type=home |title=Threat to freedom: global warning |work=Predict Weather |date=25 January 2010 |accessdate=27 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author=Ken Ring |url= http://www.predictweather.co.nz/ArticleShow.aspx?ID=211&type=home |title=Global warming in a flat-Earth |work=Predict Weather |date=1 October 2009 |accessdate=27 March 2011}}</ref> During the launch of his 2008 almanac he said that "we have a responsibility to create global warming" as "life likes warmth".<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/taranaki-daily-news/news/656270 |title=Self-taught forecaster wants warmer world |newspaper=Taranaki Daily News |date=3 October 2008 |accessdate=28 March 2011}}</ref>
== Earthquake prediction ==
Ring [[earthquake prediction|predicts earthquakes]] based on the position of the moon. On his website he says that when the moon (in particular the [[new moon]]) is at [[perigee]] (closest to the earth) it may affect the Earth's [[Mantle (geology)|mantle]] and alter the [[Earth's magnetic field|magnetic field]]. It may also draw the [[Van Allen Belt]] closer, attracting [[Particle radiation|radioactively charged particles]] towards Earth. Ring believes this combination may be responsible for earthquakes and volcanoes.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.predictweather.co.nz/ArticleShow.aspx?ID=316&type=home |title=Can earthquakes be predicted? |date=25 October 2010 |author=Ken Ring |work=Predict Weather |accessdate=31 March 2011}}</ref> Ring has predicted 221 days of increased earthquake risk for New Zealand in 2011<ref name = "WTA">{{cite news |url=http://www.times-age.co.nz/local/news/ring-prediction-dismissed/3945176/ |work=Wairarapa Times-Age |title=Ring prediction dismissed |author=Nathan Crombie |date=21 March 2011}}</ref> and more than half of the time between the start of January and the end of March as earthquake risk.<ref>{{cite news |title=Ken Ring: Can he actually predict earthquakes? |date=17 March 2011 |author=Dan Satherley |url= http://www.3news.co.nz/Ken-Ring-Can-he-actually-predict-earthquakes/tabid/1160/articleID/202642/Default.aspx |work=3 News}}</ref>
On his weekly Radio Waatea broadcast on 3 September 2010 he said "you’ll be reading about floods and winds and earthquakes and snow over the next week or so, particularly the South Island".<ref name = "tweet">{{cite web |url= http://www.3news.co.nz/Valentines-Day-tweet-predicted-Christchurch-quake-Ken-Ring/tabid/423/articleID/199449/Default.aspx |title=Valentine's Day tweet predicted Christchurch quake? Ken Ring |author=Greg Robertson |work=3 News |date=23 February 2011 |accessdate=31 March 2011}}</ref> Early the next morning a [[2010 Canterbury earthquake|7.1 magnitude earthquake]] struck Christchurch.
On 7 September 2010 he wrote on his website that there would "probably be an east/west faultline event" in Marlborough or north Canterbury "just before noon" on 20 March 2011.<ref name=Ring_March2011>{{cite web |url= http://www.predictweather.co.nz/ArticleShow.aspx?ID=306 |title=Christchurch earthquake update |first=Ken |last=Ring |date=7 September 2010 |work=Predict Weather |accessdate=19 June 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Quake prediction 'like a horoscope' |first=Tania |last=Butterfield |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/marlborough-express/news/4674668/Quake-prediction-like-a-horoscope |newspaper=The Marlborough Express |date=18 February 2011 |accessdate=9 July 2011}}</ref> The next day he wrote on Twitter, "The Christchurch earthquake was predictable. And there's another coming in 6 months." He directed readers to his website to find out just when it would be.<ref name = "tweet"/><ref>{{cite web |url= https://twitter.com/kenringweather/status/23856729753 |title=The Christchurch earthquake was predictable. And there's another coming in 6 months. See www.predictweather.com to find out when |first=Ken |last=Ring |date=8 September 2010 |work=Twitter |accessdate=7 July 2011}}</ref> Another two days later in a [[Radio Live]] interview, he told [[Marcus Lush]] that "the next one" would be "round about lunchtime on the 20th of March" and that "the South Island is going to be right in the firing line".<ref name = "Lush">{{cite news |title=Ken Ring and his natural disaster predictions – audio |date=10 September 2010 |url= http://www.radiolive.co.nz/Ken-Ring-and-his-natural-disaster-predictions/tabid/506/articleID/16022/Default.aspx |work=Radio Live}}</ref>
{{quote|The morning of 20 March 2011 sees the South island again in a big earthquake risk for all the same reasons. This date is the closest fly-past the moon does in all of 2011. The node arrives on the 20th at 9.44am. As that date coincides with lunar equinox this will probably be an east/west faultline event this time, and therefore should be more confined to a narrower band of latitude. The only east/west fault lines in NZ are in Marlborough and N Canterbury. All factors should come together for a moon-shot straight through the centre of the earth and targeting NZ. The time will be just before noon. It could be another for the history books.|Ken Ring|Predict Weather, 7 September 2010<ref name=Ring_March2011/>}}
On 14 February 2011 Ring [[Twitter|tweeted]] "Potential earthquake time for the planet between 15th–25th, especially 18th for Christchurch, +/- about 3 days."<ref name = "tweet"/><ref>{{cite web |url= https://twitter.com/kenringweather/status/36763786807345152 |title=Potential earthquake time for the planet between 15th-25th, especially 18th for Christchurch, +/- about 3 days. www.predictweather.com |first=Ken |last=Ring |date=14 February 2011 |work=Twitter |accessdate=7 July 2011}}</ref> A deadly [[2011 Canterbury earthquake|6.3 magnitude aftershock]] struck Christchurch on 22 February.
Following the earthquakes Ring received a lot of media attention. [[John Campbell (broadcaster)|John Campbell]] interviewed Ring on ''[[Campbell Live]]'' on 28 February<ref>{{cite news |title=Ken Ring: 'I predicted the Christchurch quake' |date=28 Feb 2011 |url= http://www.3news.co.nz/Ken-Ring-I-predicted-the-Christchurch-quake-/tabid/817/articleID/200226/Default.aspx |work=3 News}}</ref> and was criticised for being arrogant and not giving Ring a fair chance to speak.<ref>{{cite news |title=Viewers criticise John Campbell |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/southland-times/entertainment/4718674/Viewers-criticise-John-Campbell-interview |work=The Southland Times |date=1 March 2011}}</ref> Campbell later apologised,<ref>{{cite news |title=John Campbell to Ken Ring: I am sincerely sorry |author=John Campbell |date=1 March 2011 |work=3 News |url= http://www.3news.co.nz/John-Campbell-to-Ken-Ring-I-am-sincerely-sorry/tabid/817/articleID/200416/Default.aspx}}</ref> but his interview may have unintentionally generated sympathy for Ring.<ref>{{cite news |title=Christchurch begins to believe 'Moon Man' who predicted quakes |author=Tim Hume |date=23 March 2011 |work=The Independent |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/australasia/christchurch-begins-to-believe-moon-man-who-predicted-quakes-2250146.html}}</ref> Prior to 20 March 2011, Cabinet minister [[Nick Smith (New Zealand politician)|Nick Smith]], who has a PhD in [[geotechnical engineering]], said Ring's predictions were "reckless and irresponsible" and suggested that Ring should be "held to account for his predictions of a further earthquake in Christchurch".<ref name=twsJunS13>{{cite news |author=Alex Walls |title= Nick Smith: Ken Ring offensive; should be held to account |work=The National Business Review |quote= ACC Minister Nick Smith has said that earthquake soothsayer Ken Ring was "reckless" and "irresponsible" and that he ought to be held to account for his predictions of a further earthquake in Christchurch. |date=15 March 2011 |url= http://www.nbr.co.nz/article/nick-smith-ken-ring-offensive-should-be-held-account-ck-88242?page=2 |accessdate=19 June 2011}}</ref> Smith added that "the last thing needed by thousands of traumatised people in Canterbury, including elderly and children, is junk science and made-up predictions of future major quakes."<ref name=twsP44>{{cite news |author=Agence France-Presse |title= New Zealand sceptics defy ‘Moonman’ quake prophecy |newspaper=Canada.com |quote= Geologists, engineers and like-minded sceptics will meet in earthquake-devastated Christchurch Sunday to mock "junk science" predictions another major tremor will hit the city this weekend. |date= 14 March 2011 |url= http://www.canada.com/news/canada-at-war/Zealand+sceptics+defy+Moonman+quake+prophecy/4435517/story.html |accessdate=19 June 2011}}</ref> Smith described Ring as "scaremongering"<ref name = "Smith">{{cite news |title='Reckless' quake claims not helping, says Smith |date=20 March 2011 |work=One News |url= http://tvnz.co.nz/national-news/reckless-quake-claims-not-helping-says-smith-4073216}}</ref> and attended a lunch on 20 March at the [[Sign of the Kiwi]], close to the epicentre of the 22 February earthquake, organised by the [[New Zealand Skeptics]] organisation.<ref>{{cite news |title=Christchurch earthquake: Sceptics take aim at Ken Ring |author=Andre Hueber |date=13 March 2011 |url= http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10712024 |work=New Zealand Herald}}</ref> After the widespread death and destruction caused by the earlier earthquakes<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/christchurch-earthquake/4780793/Christchurch-earthquake-death-toll-reaches-182 |title=Christchurch earthquake death toll reaches 182 |work=Stuff |date=17 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-11183685 |title=Strong earthquake rocks New Zealand's South Island |work=BBC News |date=3 September 2010}}</ref> counsellors say his prediction for 20 March terrified "even the most rational" of people.<ref>{{cite news |title=Ken Ring's Christchurch earthquake claims 'terrifying' people |author=Stacey Wood and Kirsty Johnston |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/dominion-post/news/4776904/Rings-claims-terrifying-people |date=17 March 2011 |work=The Dominion Post}}</ref> 18 March had been made a special public holiday for Christchurch, and some residents left the city for the three-day weekend of 18–20 March, citing a mix of doubt and concern over the prediction, as well as wishing to have a break from the aftershocks and to take advantage of the long weekend.<ref>{{cite news |title=Christchurch residents flee |author=Michael Wright |date=19 March 2011 |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/christchurch-earthquake/4787664/Christchurch-residents-flee |work=Stuff.co.nz}}</ref> A 5.1 [[moment magnitude scale|magnitude]] aftershock occurred at 9:47 pm (NZDT) on 20 March,<ref>{{cite news |title=5.1 aftershock hits Christchurch |date=20 March 2011 |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/christchurch-earthquake/4789898/5-1-earthquake-hits-Christchurch |work=Stuff}}</ref> and according to his supporters validated Ring's prediction.<ref name = "told you so">{{cite news |title=Ken Ring supporters: 'Told you so!' |date=21 March 2011 |author=Dan Satherley |url= http://www.3news.co.nz/Ken-Ring-supporters-Told-you-so/tabid/1160/articleID/203272/Default.aspx |work=3 News}}</ref> Scientists contend there is no link with Ring's predictions,<ref name = "no link">{{cite news |title=5.1 quake but Moon Man link ruled out |author=Lincoln Tan and Amelia Wade |date=21 March 2011 |newspaper=New Zealand Herald |url= http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10713891}}</ref> and with a quake measuring 5 or higher occurring once every 11 days since 4 September,<ref name = "told you so"/> it was within the range expected in the ongoing aftershock pattern.<ref>{{cite news |title=No revival of a bad moon rising, Mr Ring |author=Paul Gorman |date=21 March 2011 |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/christchurch-earthquake-2011/4790241/No-revival-of-a-bad-moon-rising-Mr-Ring |work=The Press}}</ref>
David Winter, a PhD student in [[Extended evolutionary synthesis|evolutionary genetics]], analysed Ring's predictions and noted that the moon only explains a 2% variation in earthquake activity<ref>{{cite web |url= http://theatavism.blogspot.com/2011/02/ken-ring-can-predict-earthquakes-either.html |title=Ken Ring can't predict earthquakes either |first=David |last=Winter |date=1 March 2011 |work=The Atavism |accessdate=21 June 2011}}</ref> and wrote that [[Cognitive bias|cognitive]] and [[hindsight bias]] are possible reasons for so many people believing his predictions.<ref name = "WTA"/> New Zealand's [[TV3 (New Zealand)|TV3]] news channel says they have not been able to "find a single scientist, geologist or seismologist which believes in Ken Ring's theories".<ref name=twsP43>{{cite news |title= Ken Ring: 'I predicted the Christchurch quake' |newspaper=3 News |quote= We have not found a single scientist, geologist or seismologist which believes in Ken Ring's theories. |date= 28 February 2011 |url= http://www.3news.co.nz/Ken-Ring-I-predicted-the-Christchurch-quake-/tabid/817/articleID/200226/Default.aspx |accessdate=16 June 2011}}</ref> Alison Campbell, a lecturer in science education at the University of Waikato,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sciencelearn.org.nz/Science-Stories/Celebrating-Science/2007-Awards/Dr-Alison-Campbell |title=Dr Alison Campbell |date=7 May 2009 |work=Science Learning Hub |publisher=The University of Waikato |accessdate=28 June 2011}}</ref> criticised Ring's predictions for "imprecision", "inconsistencies", and being "vaguely worded", and described Ring as "hedging his bets."<ref name=campbell_1_Mar>{{cite web |url= http://sci.waikato.ac.nz/bioblog/2011/03/predicting-earthquakes-hedging.shtml |title=Predicting earthquakes: hedging your bets |first=Alison |last=Campbell |date=1 March 2011 |work=BioBlog |accessdate=28 June 2011 |quote= He's also hedging his bets – the phrasing here is so vague that just about ''any'' untoward event would count as an accurate prediction. Just what would qualify as a "severe weather event"? Will it really be "worldwide" – as in the sense of "global" – or is this statement intentionally broad so that any instance of severe weather on March 20th, anywhere in the world, could thus count as a 'correct' prediction? (What ''is'' "severe", anyway?) I have asked Ken for clarification on this, on the SciBlogs mirror of my blog, but so far – despite him saying there that "I never shy away from questions" – I’m afraid I’ve had no further clarification.}}</ref>
{{cquote|The problem is though, that such vaguely worded 'predictions', with their lack of precision, are so wide open that they lend themselves to confirmation bias. – Alison Campbell, March 2011<ref name=campbell_1_Mar/>}}
One such example of confirmation bias is a Ring prediction from 2011, which was reported in an article for local Wellington newspaper, the Upper Hutt Leader. On 14 November 2016, Kaikoura and Wellington city experienced a M7.8 earthquake. Ring was quoted in 2011 as saying "I do expect earthquake activity exceeding 7 on the Richter to come about every 11 to 13 years, as they have done in Wellington in February 1893, August 1904, August 1917, July 1929, August 1942, May 1968 and May 1992. As the last in the series of above-7s was in 1992 we can reasonably expect a 7 mag between 2013 and 2016,"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/dominion-post/news/local-papers/upper-hutt-leader/5733582/Moon-Man-predicts-big-quake-by-2016 |title=Moon Man predicts big quake by 2016 |date=5 October 2011 |work=Upper Hutt Leader |publisher=Upper Hutt Leader |accessdate=12 December 2016}}</ref> allowing a full four-year window for an earthquake to occur, making the "prediction" useless.

[[File:KAFIsm.jpg|thumb|270px| The Kolodzei Art Foundation's logo, created by [[Erik Bulatov]]]]
The '''Kolodzei Art Foundation''', Inc. promotes the [[contemporary art]] of [[Russia]] and the former Soviet Union. The Kolodzei Art Foundation often utilizes the artistic resources of the Kolodzei Collection of Russian and Eastern European Art, one of the world's largest private collections, with over 7,000 artworks by over 300 artists from Russia and the former Soviet Union.
The Foundation has held exhibitions at such museums as the [[Hermitage Museum]], the State [[Tretyakov Gallery]], the [[State Russian Museum]], the Central House of Artists, National Center for Contemporary Art, [[Harriman Institute]] at [[Columbia University]], MARS Contemporary Art Center, the [[Chelsea Art Museum]], the [[Leepa-Rattner Museum of Art]], the Bergen Museum of Art and Science, the MADI Museum, and elsewhere.
==Mission==
The Kolodzei Art Foundation, founded in 1991, arranges art exhibitions in museums, universities and cultural centers throughout the United States, Russia and Europe. Its Board of Directors includes distinguished business, diplomatic and cultural figures in US-European-Russian relations. The Kolodzei Art Foundation also arranges Russian-American cultural exchanges, grants financial stipends to artists for the purpose of studying and working in the United States, provides art supplies to artists in Russia and the former Soviet Union, and publishes books on Russian art. It is a US-based public foundation ([[501(c)3]] status).
==The Kolodzei Collection of Russian and Eastern European Art==
The Kolodzei Art Foundation often utilizes the artistic resources of the Kolodzei Collection of Russian and Eastern European Art. The Kolodzei Collection of Russian and Eastern European Art is now one of the world's largest private art collections, containing over 7,000 works by over 300 artists, including paintings, sculptures, prints, photographs and videos, all from Russia and the former Soviet Union from the 1950s through today. The Collection was started by Tatiana Kolodzei in Moscow during the late 1960s at the height of the Cold War. In 2006, the Kolodzei Collection of Russian and Eastern European Art was recognized by ''Art and Antiques Magazine'' as one of the top 100 collectors in the United States (''[[Art & Antiques|Art and Antiques]]'', March 2006, pp. 101–102).
There are now over 300 artists in the Kolodzei Collection of Russian and Eastern European Art. The Collection includes works by such well known artists of the 1960s and 1970s as [[Ilya Kabakov]], [[Komar and Melamid]], Eduard Shteinberg, [[Vladimir Nemukhin]], Pyotr Belenok, [[Erik Bulatov]], Ivan Chuikov, Francisco Infante, Viacheslav Koleichuk, Bela Levikova, Mikhail Shvartsman, [[Oleg Vassiliev (painter)|Oleg Vassiliev]], Vladimir Yankilevsky, Leonid Lamm, Valeri Yurlov, Dmitri Krasnopevtsev, [[Anatoly Zverev]], Eduard Gorokhovsky, [[Dmitri Plavinsky]], Rimma Gerlovina and Valeriy Gerlovin, {{Interlanguage link multi|Vladimir Igorevich Yakovlev|ru|3=Яковлев, Владимир Игоревич|lt=Vladimir Yakovlev}} , [[Ernst Neizvestny]], and many others. There are artists of the 1980s and 1990s such as [[Igor Novikov (painter)|Igor Novikov]], Andrei Budaev, Shimon Okshteyn, [[Dimitry Gerrman]], Farid Bogdalov, Asya Dodina, Slava Polishchuk, Olga Bulgakova, Valerii and Natasha Cherkashin, Irina Danilova, Genia Chef, Leonid Borisov, Andrei Karpov, Evgenii Gorokhovskii, Sergei Volokhov, Valery Koshlyakov, Sergei Mironenko, Andrei Filipov, Semen Agroskin, Mamut Churlu, Tatiana Antoshina, and others.
==Founders==
Tatiana Kolodzei, along with supporters from the US and Europe (including [[Norton Dodge]]), formed the Kolodzei Art Foundation shortly before the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991. Tatiana's daughter, Natalia Kolodzei (an Honorary Member of the [[Russian Academy of Arts]]), is the Executive Director. ''[[Robb Report]]'' called Natalia Kolodzei "the person to know" regarding Russian art, and "one of the most influential of Russia's young cultural figures."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://robbreport.com/Bear-Essentials.aspx|title=Bear Essentials|website=The Best Luxury Cars, Jets, Yachts, Travel, Watches {{!}} Robb Report|access-date=2016-03-10}}</ref> In 2015, Natalia Kolodzei was featured in The Robb 50 Connoisseurs: Art; Robb Report, October 2015.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://robbreport.com/paid-issue/natalia-kolodzei|title=Natalia Kolodzei|website=The Best Luxury Cars, Jets, Yachts, Travel, Watches {{!}} Robb Report|access-date=2016-03-10}}</ref>
==Selected exhibitions== (either by the Kolodzei Art Foundation or featuring works from the Kolodzei Collection of Russian and Eastern European Art)
Personal Spaces – Interactive Multimedia Works by Anna Frants, Carla Gannis, Alexandra Dementieva, Elena Gubanova and Ivan Govorkov. [[National Arts Club]], 15 Gramercy Park South, New York, 2018.
''This Leads to Fire: Russian Art from Non-Conformism to Global Capitalism. Selections from the Kolodzei Art Foundation'', [[Neuberger Museum of Art]], Purchase College, Purchase, NY, September 14, 2014 to January 11, 2015.<ref>Article on the exhibition by Hodara, Susan, Artistic Expression in a Repressive State, New York Times, November 30, 2014 https://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/30/nyregion/in-purchase-ny-an-exhibition-of-artwork-by-artists-who-worked-in-the-soviet-union.html?_r=0</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.studiointernational.com/index.php/natalia-kolodzei-interview-this-leads-to-fire-neuberger-museum|title=Natalia Kolodzei interview: ‘My dream is that every American museum has a small collection of Russian art’, Studio International|last=Kurchanova|first=Natasha|website=Studio International - Visual Arts, Design and Architecture|language=en-gb|access-date=2016-03-10}}</ref>
''Finding Freedom in Russian Art, 1961-2014. Selections from the Kolodzei Art Foundation and the Collection of Dr. Wayne F. Yakes.'' [[Paul and Lulu Hilliard University Art Museum]], University of Louisiana at Lafayette, Lafayette, LA, 2014.
''Concerning the Spiritual In Russian Art, 1965-2011. Selections from the Kolodzei Art Foundation.'' [[The Museum of Russian Art]], Minneapolis, Minnesota, 2013.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.startribune.com/museum-of-russian-art-showcases-spiritual-art-from-soviet-era-to-now/189251811/?refer=y|title=Museum of Russian Art showcases Spiritual Art from Soviet era to now|website=Star Tribune|access-date=2016-03-10}}</ref>
''Concerning the Spiritual Tradition in Russian Art. Selections from the Kolodzei Art Foundation Collection of Russian and Eastern European Art.'' Curated by Natalia Kolodzei. Chelsea Art Museum - Home of Miotte Foundation, New York, 2011
''Not Toys?!'' State [[Tretyakov Gallery]] in conjunction with 3rd Moscow Biennale) 2009
''From Non-Conformism to Feminisms: Russian Women Artists from the Kolodzei Art Foundation.'' Chelsea Art Museum - Home of the Miotte Foundation, New York 2008
''Moscow - New York = Parallel Play. From the Kolodzei Art Foundation Collection of Russian and Eastern European Art.'' National Center for Contemporary Art (NCCA), 2007, and Chelsea Art Museum - Home of the Miotte Foundation, New York, 2008<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.e-flux.com/announcements/moscow-new-york-parallel-play/|title=Moscow-New York = Parallel Play {{!}} e-flux|website=www.e-flux.com|access-date=2016-03-10}}</ref>
''Olga Bulgakova and Alexander Sitnikov. Paintings. Objects.'' State Tretyakov Gallery, Moscow, 2007
''Shimon Okshteyn. Dialogue with Objects.'' Contemporary Art Center MARS and State Russian Museum, Saint Petersburg 2007<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.e-flux.com/announcements/shimon-okshteyn/|title=Shimon Okshteyn {{!}} e-flux|website=www.e-flux.com|access-date=2016-03-10}}</ref>
''Vadim Voinov. The State Hermitage under a Full Moon.'' The State [[Hermitage Museum]], St. Petersburg, 2005-2006

''Oleg Vassiliev: Memory Speaks (Themes and Variations).'' State Tretyakov Gallery, Moscow, and the State Russian Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia 2004-2005.
''Dmitri Plavinsky—A Retrospective: Paintings, Works on Paper and Installations''. State Tretyakov Gallery, Moscow. 2004
The Kolodzei Art Foundation lent artworks to the exhibition Abstract Art XXth Century, State Russian Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia. 2001-2002
''Hurricane of Time: Selections from the Kolodzei Collection'' Villa Ormond, [[Sanremo]], Italy. 2000
''Works on Paper: Selections from the Kolodzei Collection'', Oklahoma Art Center, Oklahoma City. 1994, Long Island University, Brooklyn, NY (1999), Bergen Museum of Art (2000)
''100 Artists from Tatiana & Natalia Kolodzei Collection'', State Museum of Fine Arts of Uzbekistan in [[Tashkent]]. 1989
==Publications featuring the Kolodzei Art Collection==
*''Moscow - New York = Parallel Play. From the Kolodzei Art Foundation Collection of Russian and Eastern European Art''. Edited by Natalia Kolodzei. 2007. {{ISBN|978-0981519500}}. *''Shimon Okshteyn. Dialogue with Objects''. Introduction by Evgenia Petrova and essays by Charlotta Kotik, Donald Kuspit, José Pierre, Natalia Kolodzei, and Jenifer Borum. Palace Editions, 2006. {{ISBN|978-3-938051-80-1}} *''Vadim Voinov. The State Hermitage under a Full Moon''. St. Petersburg: State Hermitage Museum, 2005. *''Oleg Vassiliev: Memory Speaks (Themes and Variations).'' General Editor: Natalia Kolodzei, with essays by Amei Wallach, [[Andrew Solomon]], Natalia Kolodzei, Ilya Kabakov, Eric Bulatov, Victor and Margarita Tupitsyn, and Oleg Vassiliev. Published by Palace Editions, the State Russian Museum and the Kolodzei Art Foundation, in collaboration with the State Tretyakov Gallery. {{ISBN|0-9754829-2-0}}. *''The Hurricane of Time. Turn of the Century, Close of the Millennium. Selections from the Kolodzei Collection of Russian and Eastern European Art'' (1960 - 2000). Essays by Tatiana Kolodzei, Natalia Kolodzei, Alison Hilton, Valery Turchin, Enrico Crispolti. {{ISBN|0-9754829-0-4}} *''Olga Bulgakova'' ({{ISBN|9780975482964}}) and ''Alexander Sitnikov'' ({{ISBN|9780975482988}}) Including essays by Alexander Borovsky, Barbara Thiemann, Natalia Kolodzei, Alexander Rozhin and Natalia Sitnikova. Moscow: Knigi WAM, 2007 *''The "Art Constitution", the Illustrated Constitution of the Russian Federation.'' Editors: Sergey Denisov, Ivan Kolesnikov, and Peter Voice, with essays by [[Zurab Tsereteli]], Natalia Kolodzei, Ekaterina Dyogot, and Irina Kulik Moscow: Alpha-Press, in collaboration with the [[Moscow Museum of Modern Art]] and the Kolodzei Art Foundation, Inc. {{ISBN|0-9754829-1-2}}. *''Sergey Kalinin and Farid Bogdalov: Session of the Federal Assembly''. Moscow, 2004. {{ISBN|0-9754829-3-9}}.

page.title: List of Mongol and Tatar attacks in Europe

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Wars involving the Mongols]]; added [[Category:Invasions by the Mongol Empire]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
The [[Mongol invasion of Europe]] from the east took place over the course of three centuries, from the [[Middle Ages]] to the [[early modern period]].
The terms ''Tatars'' or ''Tartars'' are applied to nomadic [[Mongols|Mongolic peoples]] who, themselves, were conquered by Mongols and incorporated into their horde. They were mainly composed of [[Kipchaks]]-[[Cuman people]].
[[Mongols|Mongol]]-[[Tatars|Tatar]] [[Golden Horde]] forces led by [[Batu Khan]], (a grandson of [[Genghis Khan]]), began attacking Europe in 1223, starting with [[Cumans]], [[Volga Bulgaria]] and [[Kievan Rus'|Kievan Rus]]. They destroyed many [[Rus' (region)|Rus]] cities including [[Kiev]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://tspace.library.utoronto.ca/citd/RussianHeritage/4.PEAS/4.L/12.III.5.html|title=https://tspace.library.utoronto.ca/citd/RussianHeritage/4.PEAS/4.L/12.III.5.html|publisher=|accessdate=3 June 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120530043944/https://tspace.library.utoronto.ca/citd/RussianHeritage/4.PEAS/4.L/12.III.5.html|archivedate=30 May 2012|df=}}</ref> [[Vladimir, Russia|Vladimir]] and [[Moscow]] in the process, sparing [[Novgorod]] and [[Pskov]] however. They originally planned to continue all the way to the shores of the "Great Sea" ([[Atlantic Ocean]]). However, upon learning of the death of [[Ögedei Khan]] (third son of Genghis Khan, uncle of Batu Khan) in 1241 they returned eastwards to their steppe homelands. This, it could be argued, saved the rest of Europe from suffering the catastrophes that befell the armies and towns of Poland and Hungary, although over-stretched lines of communication and the lack of vast open tracts of pasture land might well have proved the undoing of such a venture.
==List of events== * 1223: [[Battle of Kalka River]] was fought. Mongol attack on [[Volga Bulgaria]]. [[Battle of Samara Bend]] ends with Mongol defeat. * 1236: [[Mongol invasion of Volga Bulgaria|Volga Bulgaria]] and [[Cumans]] were conquered. * 1237: [[Ryazan]] devastated. * 1238: [[Vladimir, Russia|Vladimir]] and Moscow were devastated, [[Battle of the Sit River]] is fought shortly after * 1238-1239: [[Rostov]], [[Uglich]], [[Yaroslavl]], [[Kostroma]], [[Kashin (town)|Kashin]], [[Sknyatino|Ksnyatin]], [[Gorodets, Nizhny Novgorod Oblast|Gorodets]], [[Galich, Russia|Galich]], [[Pereslavl-Zalessky|Pereslavl]], [[Yuryev-Polsky (town)|Yuriev]], [[Dmitrov]], [[Volokolamsk|Volok]], [[Tver]] and [[Torzhok]] were devastated. In the west, [[Chernihiv|Chernigov]] and [[Pereiaslav-Khmelnytskyi|Pereyaslav]] were sacked. * 1240: Destruction of [[Kiev]]. * 1241: [[Battle of Legnica]] and [[Battle of Mohi]] were fought, respectively. Devastation of parts of Poland and Hungary following Mongol victories. Some Mongol troops reaches the outskirts of Vienna and Udine. Death of [[Ögedei Khan]]; Retreat of Mongol-Tatar army. * 1258/1259: Incursion against [[Grand Duchy of Lithuania]]. * 1259/1260: Second raid against Poland. * 1264/1265: Raid against [[Thrace]]. * 1271, 1274, 1282 and 1285: Raids against [[Volga Bulgaria|Bulgaria]]. * 1275: Second raid against [[Grand Duchy of Lithuania]]. * 1284/1285: Second raid against Hungary. * 1287/1288: Third raid against Poland. * 1291: Attempted invasion of [[Serbia]]. * 1324 and 1337: Incursions against Byzantine Thrace. * 1340: Fourth raid against Poland.
The Tatars succeeded in establishing control over [[Rus' (region)|Rus]] principalities. It included both pillaging and bloody massacres in Russian cities.
* 1252: Horde of Nevruy devastated [[Pereslavl-Zalessky|Pereslavl]] and [[Suzdal]]. * 1273: Tatars twice attacked [[Novgorod Republic|Novgorod territory]], devastating [[Vologda]] and [[Bezhetsk|Bezhiza]]. * 1274: Tatars devastated [[Smolensk]] * 1275: Tatar invasion of south-eastern Russia, pillage of [[Kursk]]. * 1278: Tatars pillaged [[Principality of Ryazan|Ryazan principality]]. * 1281: The horde of [[Kovdygay]] and [[Alchiday]] destroyed [[Murom]] and [[Pereslavl-Zalessky|Pereslavl]], ruined vicinities of [[Suzdal]], [[Rostov]], [[Vladimir, Russia|Vladimir]], [[Yuryev-Polsky (town)|Yuryev]], [[Tver]] and [[Torzhok]]. * 1282: Tatar attack on [[Vladimir, Russia|Vladimir]] and [[Pereslavl-Zalessky|Pereslavl]]. * 1283: Tatars ruined [[Principality of Vorgol|Vorgol]], [[Principality of Rylsk|Rylsk]] and [[Principality of Lipetsk|Lipetsk]] principality, occupied [[Kursk]] and [[Vorgol]]. * 1285: The Tatar warlord [[Eltoray]], the son of [[Temir]], pillaged [[Ryazan]] and [[Murom]]. * 1293: The Tatar warlord [[Dyuden]] came to Russia and devastated 14 towns, including [[Murom]], Moscow, [[Kolomna]], [[Vladimir, Russia|Vladimir]], [[Suzdal]], [[Yuryev-Polsky (town)|Yuryev]], [[Pereslavl-Zalessky|Pereslavl]], [[Mozhaysk]], [[Volokolamsk|Volok]], [[Dmitrov]], [[Uglich]]. In the same summer ''Tatar tsarevitch'' Takhtamir looted [[Tver]]' principality and captured slaves in Vladimir principality. * 1347: The [[Republic of Genoa|Genoese]] possession of [[Feodosiya|Caffa]], a great trade emporium on the [[Crimean Peninsula]], came under siege by an army of [[Mongol]] warriors under the command of [[Janibeg]]. An [[epidemic]] of [[bubonic plague]] had been ravaging [[Central Asia]] before the conflict in Caffa. Brought across the [[Silk Road]], the Mongols used disease infected corpses as a [[biological weapon]]. The corpses were catapulted over the city walls, infecting the inhabitants.<ref>Svat Soucek. ''A History of Inner Asia''. [[Cambridge University Press]], 2000. {{ISBN|0-521-65704-0}}. P. 116.</ref> The Genoese traders fled, transferring the plague via their ships into the south of Europe, whence it rapidly spread. It is estimated that between one-quarter and two-thirds of [[Medieval demography|Europe's population]] died from the outbreak of the [[Black Death]] between 1348 and 1350. * 1380: Tatars were defeated in the [[Battle of Kulikovo]] by the Grand Prince of [[Muscovy]], [[Dmitri Donskoi]]. * 1382: The Golden Horde under Khan [[Tokhtamysh]] sacked Moscow, burning the city and carrying off thousands of inhabitants as slaves. Muscovy remained a [[vassal]] of the [[Golden Horde]] until * 1480: the [[Great stand on the Ugra river]]. [[File:HedwigAltarVII.jpg|thumb|160px|Mongol-Tatar warriors besiege their opponents.]] * 1506: Poland was invaded by Tatars from the [[Crimean Khanate]] with an army of 10,000 men, who were summarily destroyed. * 1521: The combined forces of Crimean Khan Mehmed Giray and his Kazan allies attacked Moscow and captured thousands of [[slavery|slaves]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allempires.com/article/index.php?q=The_Crimean_Khanate|title=The Tatar Khanate of Crimea - All Empires|publisher=|accessdate=3 June 2016}}</ref> 1552 Russian Moscow state 110,000 army with Kasym state 40,000 army occupied Kazan kahanate 30,000 army. * 1571: The Crimean khan [[Devlet I Giray]] [[Crimean Tatars invasion into Russia in 1571|devastated Moscow]] with a horde of 120,000 horsemen. * 1599: Tatar forces invaded, invading [[Lwów]] and [[Tarnopol]], but were beaten back by [[Cossack]] forces.
From 1599 the [[Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth]] suffered a series of Tatar invasions, the goal of which was to loot, pillage and capture slaves into [[slavery|jasyr]]. The borderland area to the south-east was in a state of semi-permanent warfare until the 18th century. Some researchers estimate that altogether more than 3 million people, predominantly [[Ukrainians]] but also [[Circassians]], [[Russians]], [[Belarusians]] and [[Poles]], were captured and enslaved during the time of the Crimean Khanate. A constant threat from [[Crimean Tatars]] supported the appearance of [[Cossack]]dom.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.avalanchepress.com/Soldier_Khan.php|title=Avalanche Press|publisher=|accessdate=3 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.americanthinker.com/2005/04/the_living_legacy_of_jihad_sla.html|title=Articles: The living legacy of jihad slavery|publisher=|accessdate=3 June 2016}}</ref>
For years the [[Khanate of Kazan|Khanates of Kazan]] and [[Astrakhan Khanate|Astrakhan]] routinely raided Rus principalities for slaves and to plunder towns. Russian chronicles record about 40 raids of [[List of Kazan khans|Kazan Khans]] on the Russian territories in the first half of the 16th century.<ref>The Full Collection of the Russian Annals, vol.13, SPb, 1904</ref> [[Muscovy]] was also being invaded by the [[Nogai Horde]] and [[Crimean Khanate]] which were successors of the [[Golden Horde]].
In the beginning of the 16th century the wild steppe began near old [[Ryazan]] on the [[Oka River]] and Elets on the Sosna, inflow of the [[Don River, Russia|Don]]. Crimean Tatars chose to proceed along watersheds for their incursions. The main way to Moscow was "[[Muravsky Trail|Muravski shliach]]", from the Crimean Perekop up to [[Tula, Russia|Tula]] between the rivers of two basins, Dnieper and Northern [[Donets]]. Having penetrated deep in the populated areas about 100-200 kilometers, the Tatars turned back and, having unwrapped wide wings, looted and captured slaves. Until the early 18th century, the khanate maintained a massive [[slave trade]] with the [[Ottoman Empire]]. Captives were sold to Turkey and the Middle East. In [[Crimea]], about 75% of the population consisted of slaves.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/blackhistory/article-24157|title=Welcome to Encyclopædia Britannica's Guide to Black History|publisher=|accessdate=3 June 2016}}</ref> The Crimean city of [[Caffa]] was the main [[slavery|slave market]].
Annually, Moscow mobilized in the spring up to 65,000 soldiers for boundary service. The defensive lines were applied, consisting of a circuit of fortresses and cities. [[Cossacks]] and young noblemen were organized into sentry and patrol services that observed [[Crimean Tatars]] and nomads of Nogai Horde on the steppe. About 30 major Tatar raids were recorded into [[Tsardom of Russia|Muscovite]] territories between 1558-1596.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://coursesa.matrix.msu.edu/~fisher/hst373/readings/inalcik6.html|title=Inalcik. Servile Labor|publisher=|accessdate=3 June 2016}}</ref>
To protect from the invasions of the [[Nogai Horde]] between the [[Volga River|Volga]] and [[Irtysh]] rivers, the Volga cities of [[Samara, Russia|Samara]] in 1586, [[Tsaritsyn]] in 1589, [[Saratov]] in 1590 were founded.
The [[Crimean Khanate]] was one of the strongest powers in Eastern Europe until the 18th century. The Russian population of the borderland suffered annual Tatar invasions and tens of thousands of soldiers were required to protect the southern boundaries. This was a heavy burden for the state, and slowed its social and economic development. Since Crimean Tatars did not permit settlement of Russians to southern regions where the soil is better and the season is long enough, Muscovy had to depend on poorer regions and labour-intensive agriculture. [[Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth|Poland-Lithuania]], [[Moldavia]] and [[Wallachia]] were also subjected to extensive slave raiding. The Crimean Khanate was conquered by the [[Russian Empire]] in 1783, bringing an end to Mongol and Tatar rule in Europe. The [[Turkic migration|Turkic]] invasion in [[Anatolia]] (previously populated by some European nations), [[Cyprus]] and the [[Balkans]] remains unchanged.
Historians estimate that up to half of Hungary's two million population at that time were victims of the [[Mongol invasion of Europe]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-34789/Hungary|title=Hungary - history - geography|publisher=|accessdate=3 June 2016}}</ref> About half of the [[Kievan Rus|Russian]] population may have died during the [[Mongol invasion of Rus']].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.parallelsixty.com/history-russia.shtml|title=History of Russia from Early Slavs history and Kievan Rus to Romanovs dynasty|publisher=|accessdate=3 June 2016}}</ref> [[Colin McEvedy]] (''Atlas of World Population History, 1978'') estimates the population of Russia-in-Europe dropped by 500,000 people, from 7.5 to 7 million in 1300.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://users.erols.com/mwhite28/warstat0.htm#Mongol|title=WAR STATS REDIRECT|publisher=|accessdate=3 June 2016}}</ref> In some areas of Poland more than 70% of the population was slaughtered, e.g. at the silver mines of Rosperk (Rozbark), next to [[Bytom]] while one of the (at least) two raids around 75% were killed and the looted silver was used to build the massive Silver Tree fountain of [[Karakorum]].

{{about|the tradition at the University of Cambridge|the celebratory week in Argentina|May Revolution}}
[[Image:cmglee_Cambridge_St_Johns_May_Ball_2014_fireworks.jpg|thumb|300px|Fireworks of the [[St John's College, Cambridge|St John's College]] May Ball 2014 viewed from Castle Mound.]] [[Image:Suicide Sunday 2012 cardboard boat race.jpg|thumb|300px|Some participants of the [[cardboard boat race]] on ''Suicide Sunday'' 2012.]]
'''May Week''' is the name used in the [[University of Cambridge]] to refer to a period at the end of the academic year. Originally May Week took place in the week during May before year-end exams began.<ref>{{cite web|title=May Week: balls, boats and bubbly|url=http://www.kings.cam.ac.uk/archive-centre/archive-month/july-2011.html|website=King's College, Cambridge|accessdate=6 July 2014}}</ref> Nowadays, May Week takes place in June after exams, and is a cause for great celebration amongst the students of the University. Highlights of the week include [[Bumps race|Bumps races]], [[May Ball]]s, [[June Event]]s and [[garden party|garden parties]].
==History==
May Week festivities were originally held in May, in the final week before exams; however, the May boat races, also known as the [[May Bumps]], moving toward June, right after exams to celebrate the year end.<ref>"We had a Ball" - William Ham Bevan. Cambridge Alumni Magazine, Issue 72 (Easter 2014)</ref>
==Suicide Sunday== ''Suicide Sunday'' is the name used at [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge University]] to refer to the Sunday immediately after the end of the spring term (known as Easter Term). By this Sunday, all students have finished exams but most of the results have not been published, so it is traditionally a period of nerves and suspense. The name, however, refers to the celebration that students haven't committed suicide due to stress of exams.{{fact|date=May 2012}} The event is for current students of the University of Cambridge but is frequented by former students that indulge in the student lifestyle. A student-led campaign in 2015 encouraged use of the name "MayWeek Sunday" instead, though "Suicide Sunday" continues to persist among some students and the public.
The Cardboard Boat Race is a main attraction to Suicide Sunday, offering an alternative to the many garden parties and more serious boating. The first race was in 2010, with three boats from Magdalene College (The Galleon - Graham Forrest, Konrad Newton and Peter O'Brien; The Canoe - Doug Byatt, Matthew Schabas and Dominic White; Skippy - Ian Drummond, Julian Wesolowski and Tom Wilson). In 2011, the race was opened to other colleges.<ref>{{cite web |title=2011 Cardboard Boat Race |url=https://www.facebook.com/events/822698074443954/ |website=Facebook}}</ref>

'''Molokai Ka Hula Piko''' is an annual [[festival]] of the [[hula]], held for three days every spring in [[Kaana]], [[Molokai]]. ''Ka Hula Piko'' in [[Hawaiian language|Hawaiian]] means the "center of the hula dance".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.aloha-hawaii.com/molokai/things-to-do/attractions/molokai-ka-hula-piko/|title=Molokai Ka Hula Piko - Aloha Hawaii|last=Travel|first=Aloha Condos -|work=Aloha Hawaii|access-date=2018-06-12|language=en-US}}</ref>
== History == The first festival was in 1991 by the Molokai Visitors Association and [[John Kaimikaua]], a [[Kumu Hula]]. It is currently organized by the Halau Hula o Kukunaokala.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://mauinow.com/2016/05/31/molokai-ka-hula-piko-celebrates-milestone-anniversary/|title=Maui Now: Moloka’i Ka Hula Piko Celebrates Milestone Anniversary|work=Maui Now {{!}} Moloka’i Ka Hula Piko Celebrates Milestone Anniversary|access-date=2018-06-12|language=en-US}}</ref>
It is held in annually in Kaana because according to Hawaiian legend, [[Laka]], now regarded as the goddess of hula, created hula at Pu'u Nana, a sacred hill in Kaana, before spreading the art form across the islands.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.discover-oahu.com/History-Of-Hula.html|title=History Of Hula|access-date=2018-06-12}}</ref>
== Festival == The festival begins with an early-morning ceremony at Puʻu Nana.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/events/moloka-i-ka-hula-piko/a/poi-fes/1299463/1006041|title=Molokaʻi Ka Hula Piko|website=www.lonelyplanet.com|language=en|access-date=2018-06-12}}</ref> It then continues with a [[ho'olaule'a]], lectures, and other activities intended to educate and spread awareness of hula as an art form.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://themolokaidispatch.com/ka-hula-piko-festival-2012/|title=Ka Hula Piko Festival 2012 {{!}} The Molokai Dispatch|date=2012-04-25|work=The Molokai Dispatch|access-date=2018-06-12|language=en-US}}</ref>
== See also ==
* [[Merrie Monarch Festival]]
