revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{Infobox stadium | name = The Whistler Sliding Centre | image = [[Image:Whistler bobsleigh.jpg|300px|alt=Venue located on a mountainside.]] | caption = The Whistler Sliding Centre shown in June 2008. The refrigeration plant is shown behind turn 16. | location = [[Whistler, British Columbia]], Canada | coordinates = {{coord|50|6|27|N|122|56|42|W|display=inline}} | broke_ground = 1 June 2005 | built = 1 June 2005 to November 2007 | opened = 19 December 2007 | owner = VANOC (2005 to 2010), Whistler 2010 Sports Legacies (since the end of the 2010 Winter Olympics) | operator = VANOC (2005 to 2010), Whistler 2010 Sports Legacies (since the end of the 2010 Winter Olympics) | surface = Reinforced concrete with ammonia refrigeration piping that is turned on to create {{convert|2|to|5|cm|in|abbr=on}} of ice. | scoreboard = Yes | cost = C$105 million | architect = Stantec Architecture Limited | project_manager = Heatherbrae | services engineer = Western Pacific Enterprises GP/ Cimco Refrigeration (Toromont Industries Limited) | general_contractor = Emil Anderson Construction Inc. | main_contractors = Emil Anderson Construction Inc. | capacity = 12,000 | dimensions = (All from
'''Bobsleigh/ Skeleton:''' {{convert|1450|m|ft|abbr=on}}
'''Luge – men's singles:''' {{convert|1374|m|ft|abbr=on}}
'''Luge – women's singles/ men's doubles:''' {{convert|1198|m|ft|abbr=on}}
'''Junior:''' {{convert|953|m|ft|abbr=on}} }} The '''Whistler Sliding Centre''' ({{lang-fr|link=no|Centre des sports de glisse de Whistler}}) is a Canadian [[bobsleigh]], [[luge]], and [[skeleton (sport)|skeleton]] track located in [[Whistler, British Columbia]], that is {{convert|125|km|mi|abbr=on}} north of [[Vancouver]]. The centre is part of the [[Whistler Blackcomb]] resort, which comprises two ski mountains separated by [[Fitzsimmons Creek]]. Located on the lowermost slope of the northern mountain (Blackcomb Mountain), Whistler Sliding Centre hosted the [[bobsleigh]], [[luge]], and [[skeleton (sport)|skeleton]] competitions for the [[2010 Winter Olympics]]. Design work started in late 2004 with construction taking place from June 2005 to December 2007. Bobsledders [[Pierre Lueders]] and [[Justin Kripps]] of Canada took the first run on the track on 19 December 2007. Certification took place in March 2008 with over 200 runs from six different start houses (the place where the sleds start their runs), and was approved both by the [[International Bobsleigh and Tobogganing Federation]] (FIBT) and the [[International Luge Federation]] (FIL). Training runs took place in late 2008 in preparation for the World Cup events in all three sports in early 2009. World Cup competitions were held in February 2009 for bobsleigh, luge, and skeleton. The top speed for all World Cup events set by German luger [[Felix Loch]] at {{convert|153.98|km/h|mph|abbr=on}}. In late 2009, more training took place in preparation for the Winter Olympics. On 12 February 2010, the day of the [[2010 Winter Olympics opening ceremony|Olympic opening ceremonies]], Georgian luger [[Nodar Kumaritashvili]] was killed during a training run while reportedly going {{convert|143.3|km/h|mph|abbr=on}}. This resulted in the [[Luge at the 2010 Winter Olympics – Men's singles|men's singles]] event being moved to the [[Luge at the 2010 Winter Olympics – Women's singles|women's singles]] and [[Luge at the 2010 Winter Olympics – Doubles|men's doubles]] start house while both the women's singles and men's doubles event were moved to the junior start house. During actual luge competition at the 2010 Winter Olympics, there were only two crashes, which resulted in one withdrawal. Skeleton races on 18–19 February had no crashes though two skeleton racers were disqualified for technical reasons. Bobsleigh competitions had crashes during all three events. This resulted in supplemental training for both the [[Bobsleigh at the 2010 Winter Olympics – Two-woman|two-woman]] and the [[Bobsleigh at the 2010 Winter Olympics – Four-man|four-man]] event following crashes during the [[Bobsleigh at the 2010 Winter Olympics – Two-man|two-man]] event. Modifications were made to the track after the two-man event to lessen the frequency of crashes as well. A 20-page report was released by the FIL to the [[International Olympic Committee]] (IOC) on 12 April 2010 and to the public on FIL's website on 19 April 2010 regarding Kumaritashvili's death. Safety concerns at Whistler affected the track design for the [[Sliding Center Sanki]] that was used for the [[2014 Winter Olympics]] in [[Sochi]]. This included track simulation and mapping to reduce top speeds by {{convert|6|to|9|km/h|mph|abbr=on}} for the Sochi track. Constructed on part of [[First Nations]] spiritual grounds, the track won two provincial concrete construction awards in 2008 while the refrigeration plant earned Canada's [[Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design]] "gold" certification two years later. ==History== ===Awarding and construction (2004–07)=== At the 115th IOC Session held at [[Prague]] in 2003, Vancouver was chosen to host the [[2010 Winter Olympics]] over [[Pyeongchang County|Pyeongchang]], South Korea, and [[Salzburg]], Austria.{{Cite web|title=Past Olympic city post election results. |publisher=Gamesbids.com |date=20 June 2010 |url=http://www.gamesbids.com/eng/past.html |accessdate=20 June 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xFvf0ufx?url=http://www.gamesbids.com/eng/past.html |archivedate=17 March 2011 |df= }} On 15 November 2004, it was announced that [[Stantec]] Architecture Limited, which designed the [[Utah Olympic Park bobsleigh/luge/skeleton track|2002 Winter Olympic bobsleigh, luge, and skeleton track]] in [[Park City, Utah]], in the United States, would provide detail design and site master plan of the track. The company was advised by the German track engineering firm IBG.{{Cite web|title = VANOC selects designer for Whistler Sliding Centre.|publisher = [[Vancouver Organizing Committee for the 2010 Olympic and Paralympic Winter Games]] (VANOC)|date = 15 November 2004| url = http://www.vancouver2010.com/olympic-news/n/news/vanoc-selects-designer-for-whistler-sliding-centre_35924mq.html|accessdate =11 February 2008}}{{Cite web|title = Leistungsspektrum Planungphase|publisher = IBG-Gurgel|url = http://ibg-gurgel.gmxhome.de/tipps.html|accessdate = 1 April 2010|language = de|archive-url = https://archive.is/20110719033832/http://ibg-gurgel.gmxhome.de/tipps.html#|archive-date = 19 July 2011|dead-url = yes|df = dmy-all}} IBG had designed the tracks used in [[Oberhof bobsleigh, luge, and skeleton track|Oberhof]], Germany, the [[1988 Winter Olympics]] in ([[Canada Olympic Park bobsleigh, luge, and skeleton track|Calgary]]) and the [[2006 Winter Olympics]] ([[Cesana Pariol]]). The German firm is also the designer of the Russian National Sliding Centre, the venue for the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi. Site construction of the facility began on 1 June 2005 following environmental approval from the [[Canadian Environmental Assessment Act]].{{Cite web|title = Whistler Sliding Centre Environmental Screening Process.|publisher = VANOC|date = 8 June 2005|url = http://www.vancouver2010.com/dl/00/03/62/05-06-08-wsc-ceaa-backgrounder-en_28d-IT.pdf|accessdate =11 February 2008}}{{Cite web|title = Preliminary site preparation begins on schedule at the Whistler Sliding Centre|publisher = VANOC|date = 7 June 2005|url = http://www.vancouver2010.com/olympic-news/n/news/preliminary-site-preparation-begins-on-schedule-at-the-whistler-sliding-centre-following-environmental-screening-approval_36200HU.html| accessdate =11 February 2008}} Safety and security was then put in place on the site. During its peak of construction activities in the summer of 2006, more than 500 workers were involved both at the Sliding Centre and at the Whistler Nordic Venue (now [[Whistler Olympic Park]]).{{Cite web|title = Construction Update: Whistler venues taking shape.|publisher = VANOC|date = 25 July 2006|url = http://www.vancouver2010.com/olympic-news/n/news/feature-stories/construction-update--whistler-venues-taking-shape_38184ai.html|accessdate =11 February 2008}} A core group of 60 workers was involved with track construction from June 2005 to December 2007.{{Cite web|title = Pride in a job well done.|publisher = VANOC|date = 14 December 2007|url = http://www.vancouver2010.com/olympic-news/n/news/feature-stories/pride-in-a-job-well-done_39392qT.html|accessdate =11 February 2008}} Basic track construction was completed in November 2007 though fit-out and testing continued into 2008.{{Cite web|title = More than two years before Games begin, construction completed at all Whistler-based Vancouver 2010 competition venues.|publisher = VANOC|date = 13 December 2007|url = http://www.vancouver2010.com/olympic-news/n/news/more-than-two-years-before-games-begin--construction-completed-at-all-whistler-based-vancouver-2010-competition-venues_37750ty.html|accessdate =11 February 2008}} ===First testing and certification (2007–08)=== The first run was on 19 December 2007 with Canadian bobsledder Pierre Lueders and his brakeman Justin Kripps starting at the Junior Start house (Location where the sliders start their run on the track) {{convert|520|m|ft|abbr=on}} down the {{convert|1450|m|ft|abbr=on}} track.{{Cite web|title = Canadian bobsleigh hero takes first test runs at The Whistler Sliding Centre.|publisher = VANOC|date = 21 December 2007|url = http://www.vancouver2010.com/olympic-news/n/news/canadian-bobsleigh-hero-takes-first-test-runs-at-the-whistler-sliding-centre_37790bS.html|accessdate =11 February 2008}}{{Cite web|title = Leuders Takes First Run on 2010 Winter Olympic Track.|publisher = [[FIBT]]|url = {{FIBT link|url1 = http://www.fibt.com/index.php?id=88&tx_ttnews|bracket1 = pointer|url2 = =35&tx_ttnews|bracket2 = tt_news|url3 = =261&tx_ttnews|bracket3 = backPid|url4 = =171&cHash=024e6ea651|fibtlink = no|cite = yes}}|date = 21 December 2007|accessdate =9 December 2009}} A total of six runs were made under the auspices of the FIBT. The Canadian Luge Association opened a branch at the track in February 2008.{{Cite web|title = Team Canada not to compete in the final – Office in Whistler opened.|publisher = International Luge Federation |date = 13 February 2008|url = {{FIL-Luge link|url1 = http://www.fil-luge.org/News-Detail.155.0.html?&tx_ttnews|bracket1 = pS|url2 = =1201820400&tx_ttnews|bracket2 = pL|url3 = =2505599&tx_ttnews|bracket3 = arc|url4 = =1&tx_ttnews|bracket4 = pointer|url5 = =1&tx_ttnews|bracket5 = tt_news|url6 = =2863&tx_ttnews|bracket6 = backPid|url7 = =157&cHash=33f1a21341|fil-lugelink = no|cite = yes}}|accessdate =13 February 2008}} Luge tests occurred in late February 2008 and among the participants were [[Tatjana Hüfner]] (Germany), [[Erin Hamlin]] (United States), [[Armin Zöggeler]] (Italy), and [[Regan Lauscher]] (Canada).{{Cite web|title = Homologation at Whistler Sliding Center.|publisher = FIL|date = 27 February 2008|url = {{FIL-Luge link|url1 = http://www.fil-luge.org/News-Detail.155.0.html?&tx_ttnews|bracket1 = pS|url2 = =1201820400&tx_ttnews|bracket2 = pL|url3 = =2505599&tx_ttnews|bracket3 = arc|url4 = =1&tx_ttnews|bracket4 = tt_news|url5 = =2991&tx_ttnews|bracket5 = backPid|url6 = =157&cHash=cf92f7aa05|fil-lugelink = no|cite = yes}}|accessdate =4 March 2008}} Bobsleigh participants during certification in March 2008 included [[Sandra Kiriasis]] (Germany), Lueders (Canada), and [[Shauna Rohbock]] (United States) while skeleton participants included [[Kristan Bromley]] (Great Britain), [[Kerstin Jürgens]] (Szymkowiak since summer 2008 – Germany), and [[Jon Montgomery]] (Canada).{{Cite web|title = Homologation Process Completed at 2010 Olympic Track.|publisher = FIBT|date = 11 March 2008|url = {{FIBT link|url1 = http://www.fibt.com/index.php?id=88&tx_ttnews|bracket1 = pointer|url2 = =25&tx_ttnews|bracket2 = tt_news|url3 = =365&tx_ttnews|bracket3 = backPid|url4 = =171&cHash=7c90383a48|fibtlink = no|cite = yes}}|accessdate =11 March 2008}} Over 200 runs were taken from six different starting positions on the track.{{Cite web|title = The Whistler Sliding Centre homologation process complete.|publisher = VANOC|date = 9 March 2008|url = http://www.vancouver2010.com/olympic-news/n/news/the-whistler-sliding-centre-homologation-process-complete_37220eY.html| accessdate =11 March 2008}} Praise was given both by the FIBT and the FIL over the successful certification of the track. The Vancouver Organizing Committee ([[VANOC]]) reviewed the recommendations made from both the FIBT and the FIL to fine tune the track. Canadian teams continued testing and training at the track until 20 March 2008. A total of 2155 runs (335 bobsleigh, 1077 luge, and 743 skeleton) took place at the track with a total of 15 crashes. Final track inspection by the FIL Executive Board took place 25–27 September 2008 before the International Training Week later that year.{{Cite web|title = 2010 Olympic Winter Games already on the horizon.|publisher = FIL|date = 23 September 2008|url = {{FIL-Luge link|url1 = http://www.fil-luge.org/News-Detail.155.0.html?&tx_ttnews|bracket1 = pS|url2 = =1220220000&tx_ttnews|bracket2 = pL|url3 = =2591999&tx_ttnews|bracket3 = arc|url4 = =1&tx_ttnews|bracket4 = tt_news|url5 = =3365&tx_ttnews|bracket5 = backPid|url6 = =157&cHash=10f8b24856|fil-lugelink = no|cite = yes}}|accessdate =3 October 2008}} ===2008–09 Luge World Cup, including training=== International Training Week for luge took place at the track 7–15 November 2008.{{Cite web|title = First crucial test for Olympic luge track in Whistler.|publisher = FIL|date = 4 November 2008|url = {{FIL-Luge link|url1 = http://www.fil-luge.org/News-Detail.155.0.html?&tx_ttnews|bracket1 = pS|url2 = =1225494000&tx_ttnews|bracket2 = pL|url3 = =2591999&tx_ttnews|bracket3 = arc|url4 = =1&tx_ttnews|bracket4 = tt_news|url5 = =3471&tx_ttnews|bracket5 = backPid|url6 = =157&cHash=fe44a9375d|fil-lugelink = no|cite = yes}}|accessdate =21 November 2008}} A total of 2482 runs took place during the training with several injuries occurring, most notably Loch, the [[FIL World Luge Championships 2008|2008 men's singles world champion]], who injured his shoulder.{{Cite web |title = World Champion Felix Loch injured|publisher = FIL|date = 20 November 2008|url = {{FIL-Luge link|url1 = http://www.fil-luge.org/News-Detail.155.0.html?&tx_ttnews|bracket1 = pS|url2 = =1225494000&tx_ttnews|bracket2 = pL|url3 = =2591999&tx_ttnews|bracket3 = arc|url4 = =1&tx_ttnews|bracket4 = tt_news|url5 = =3499&tx_ttnews|bracket5 = backPid|url6 = =157&cHash=e5f25c67da|fil-lugelink = no|cite = yes}}|accessdate =21 November 2008}} In a 9 December 2008 press release, the Centre was continuing certification by adding protections on the track against crashes and weather.{{Cite web|title = VANOC Board of Directors approves revised budget in principle; Jack Poole re-elected as chairman.|publisher = VANOC|date = 9 December 2008|url = http://www.vancouver2010.com/olympic-news/n/news/vanoc-board-of-directors-approves-revised-budget-in-principle--jack-poole-re-elected-as-chairman_61802cL.html|accessdate =10 December 2008}} FIL President [[Josef Fendt]] stated that the track's speed was too high with top speeds reaching {{convert|149|km/h|mph|abbr=on}} during training.{{Cite web|title = FIL President Fendt has speed limit in mind.|publisher = FIL|date = 12 December 2008|url = {{FIL-Luge link|url1 = http://www.fil-luge.org/News-Detail.155.0.html?&tx_ttnews|bracket1 = pS|url2 = =1228086000&tx_ttnews|bracket2 = pL|url3 = =2678399&tx_ttnews|bracket3 = arc|url4 = =1&tx_ttnews|bracket4 = pointer|url5 = =1&tx_ttnews|bracket5 = tt_news|url6 = =3697&tx_ttnews|bracket6 = backPid|url7 = =157&cHash=dcfac1e364|fil-lugelink = no|cite = yes}}|accessdate =13 December 2008}} From the 2482 runs executed during the International Training week for luge, there were 73 crashes, a crash rate of three percent which was normal during new track testing. Three lugers, including Loch, were sent to the hospital, but were later released. Italy's Zöggeler stated that "The track can be tackled." and "does not see big problems for the athletes" while Fendt called for the top track speed for future tracks to be lowered to {{convert|135|or|136|km/h|mph|abbr=on}} where possible. For the 2008–09 World Cup season at the Centre, 15115 runs were made for bobsleigh (2153), luge (9672), and skeleton (3290). After the World Cup event on 20–21 February 2009, Austria's [[Andreas Linger]] described the track as "fast, incredibly fast."{{Cite web|title = 153,98 km/h – new speed record at the "Whistler Sliding Center".|publisher = FIL|date = 23 February 2009|url = {{FIL-Luge link|url1 = http://www.fil-luge.org/News-Detail.155.0.html?&tx_ttnews|bracket1 = pS|url2 = =1233442800&tx_ttnews|bracket2 = pL|url3 = =2419199&tx_ttnews|bracket3 = arc|url4 = =1&tx_ttnews|bracket4 = tt_news|url5 = =10387&tx_ttnews|bracket5 = backPid|url6 = =157&cHash=602572b57f|fil-lugelink = no|cite = yes}}|accessdate =23 February 2009}} Loch stated that luge speeds for men's singles reached {{convert|100|km/h|mph|abbr=on}} before turn three at the women's singles and men's doubles' start house. A total of 2818 runs for bobsleigh, luge, and skeleton were made at the track during the four-week time period for the World Cup events.{{Cite web|title = The Whistler Sliding Centre wraps up World Cup events. Sliding sport events charm sold-out crowds, yields track records, and produce top speeds.|publisher = VANOC|date = 21 February 2009|url = http://www.vancouver2010.com/olympic-news/n/news/the-whistler-sliding-centre-wraps-up-world-cup-events.-sliding-sport-events-charm-sold-out-crowds--yield-track-records-and-produce-top-speeds-_64028zJ.html|accessdate =24 February 2009}} FIL President Fendt stated that "[my] technical delegate told me this week that the Games could start tomorrow and the track would be ready." and he appreciated the whole Whistler Sliding Centre At the 2008–09 World Cup season finale, 135 athletes participated (67 men, 42 women, and 26 doubles) though 144 athletes from 23 nations were registered. During the Luge World Cup event that weekend, 186 runs took place with 16 crashes. ===2008–09 Bobsleigh and Skeleton World Cup and training=== [[File:Jon Montgomery.jpg|thumb|alt=A man celebrating victory in a competition.|2010 Winter Olympic men's skeleton champion Jon Montgomery of Canada was one of the first skeleton racers to test the Sliding Centre track.]] The first [[2008-09 Bobsleigh World Cup|bobsleigh]] and [[2008-09 Skeleton World Cup|skeleton]] training week took place on 25–31 January 2009 to prepare for their respective World Cup events on 5–7 February 2009.{{Cite web|title = Team Event in St. Moritz Cancelled.|publisher = FIBT|date = 17 January 2009|url = {{FIBT link|url1 = http://www.fibt.com/index.php?id=88&tx_ttnews|bracket1 = pointer|url2 = =13&tx_ttnews|bracket2 = tt_news|url3 = =485&tx_ttnews|bracket3 = backPid|url4 = =171&cHash=76ff6c35aa|fibtlink = no|cite = yes}}|accessdate =18 January 2009}} A total of 250 competitors from 24 nations took part in the World Cup practice for all five events (Bobsleigh two-man, bobsleigh two-woman, bobsleigh four-man, and men's and women's skeleton).{{Cite web|title = Testing successfully complete at bobsleigh and skeleton sport event. Sold-out crowd cheers sliding athletes from around the world.|publisher = VANOC|date = 7 February 2009|url = http://www.vancouver2010.com/olympic-news/n/news/testing-successfully-complete-at-bobsleigh-and-skeleton-sport-event.-sold-out-crowd-cheers-on-sliding-athletes-from-around-the-world--_63250Gx.html|accessdate =8 February 2009}} Competition and weather affected testing and World Cup runs for the two-week time period. A team of 118 personnel and 276 volunteers worked consecutive weeks at the Training Week and World Cup events. Track director Craig Lehto stated that the volunteer efforts were similar to what he had seen both at the [[2002 Winter Olympics]] in [[Salt Lake City]] and the 1988 Winter Olympics in [[Calgary]]. The final two days of competition had 3000 total spectators. Medical services, led by VANOC and FIBT medical director Dr. David McDonagh, tested themselves with [[first responder]] care and mock scenarios that included athlete extraction from the sled if the accident was severe enough. These services were tested again during the [[2008-09 Luge World Cup|Luge World Cup]] competition on 20–21 February 2009. A total of 15,000 spectators attended all five days for the bobsleigh, luge, and skeleton World Cup events, all sold out. FIBT President [[Robert H. Storey]] stated that the Centre "... is fast, technical, demanding, and interesting.". A total of 235 athletes participated in the 2008–09 World Cup event (92 four-man, 54 two-man, 40 two-woman, 28 men's skeleton, and 21 women's skeleton). ===2009–10 World Cups, including training=== A paid training session took place 27 October – 7 November 2009 at the Centre for bobsleigh teams in preparation for the 2010 Games.{{Cite web|title = Lake Placid to Host 2013 World Championship.|publisher = FIBT|date = 31 May 2009|url = {{FIBT link|url1 = http://www.fibt.com/index.php?id=88&tx_ttnews|bracket1 = pointer|url2 = =20&tx_ttnews|bracket2 = tt_news|url3 = =565&tx_ttnews|bracket3 = backPid|url4 = =171&cHash=6275441d92|fibtlink = no|cite = yes}}|accessdate =20 June 2010}} On 9–15 November 2009, a second International Training Week for luge took place in preparation for the 2010 Games with the participation of 156 athletes from 27 nations.{{Cite web|title = Exactly four months before the opening ceremony on February 12, 2010.|publisher = FIL|date = 12 October 2009|url = {{FIL-Luge link|url1 = http://www.fil-luge.org/News-Detail.155.0.html?&tx_ttnews|bracket1 = pS|url2 = =1254348000&tx_ttnews|bracket2 = pL|url3 = =2681999&tx_ttnews|bracket3 = arc|url4 = =1&tx_ttnews|bracket4 = tt_news|url5 = =10777&tx_ttnews|bracket5 = backPid|url6 = =157&cHash=1fa8ff5b97|fil-lugelink = no|cite = yes}}|accessdate =15 October 2009}}{{Cite web|title = Hüfner: "Scrutinize ideal racing line and sled configuration"|publisher = FIL|date = 9 November 2009|url = {{FIL-Luge link|url1= http://www.fil-luge.org/News-Detail.155.0.html?&tx_ttnews|bracket1 = tt_news|url2= =10825&tx_ttnews|bracket2= backPid|url3= =45&cHash=4707727a33|fil-lugelink = no|cite = yes}}|accessdate =12 November 2009}} Venezuela's [[Werner Hoeger]] was knocked unconscious during a practice run on 13 November 2009 and was denied any further make-up runs. During training that week, Hoeger expressed concern about the safety of the track. These concerns called for the resignation of track director Ed Moffat, father of lugers [[Chris Moffat|Chris]] and [[Mike Moffat (luger)|Mike]], to offer equal runs to all lugers in future events, to have Canada forfeit any extra training runs that were negotiated for the 2014 Winter Olympics, and for the Canadian Luge Association be reprimanded for unethical actions and not providing a safe sliding environment, especially after speeds were {{convert|10|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} higher than expected.{{Cite web|last = Kerby|first = Trey|title = 'Nearly every athlete is scared to death' of the Olympic luge track.|publisher = Yahoo! Sports|date = 18 February 2010|url = https://sports.yahoo.com/olympics/vancouver/blog/fourth_place_medal/post/-Nearly-every-athlete-is-scared-to-death-of-the?urn=oly,220628| accessdate =19 February 2010}} Canadian Luge Association officials declined to comment though they stated to the ''[[New York Times]]'' that the lugers received up to three times the amount of training runs offered in the run-up to the [[2006 Winter Olympics]] at [[Cesana Pariol]]. Team Canada (luge) did not participate in the [[2009–10 Luge World Cup|World Cup]] event in [[Lillehammer]], Norway during 12–13 December 2009 to train at the Sliding Centre and to compete at the Canadian National Championships that took place on 17 December 2009.{{Cite web|title = National Championships in Whistler on December 17, 2009.|publisher = FIL|date = 9 December 2009|url = {{FIL-Luge link|url1 = http://www.fil-luge.org/News-Detail.155.0.html?&tx_ttnews|bracket1 = tt_news|url2 = =11005&tx_ttnews|bracket2 = backPid|url3 = =307&cHash=81bc891ecb|fil-lugelink = no|cite = yes}}|accessdate =9 December 2009}} A training restriction went into effect on 31 December 2009 where only host nation Canada and athletes from developing nations were allowed to train before the 2010 Games. For the 2009–10 season, there were a total of 15736 runs among bobsleigh (2512), luge (8794), and skeleton (4070) with a total of 115 crashes among the three sliding disciplines. ===Public opening and post-Olympic usage=== The Centre's official website was launched in late June 2008.{{Cite web|title = Official website|publisher = The Whistler Sliding Centre|url = http://whistlerslidingcentre.com/|accessdate =3 July 2008}} Public self-guided walking tours ran from 3 July through 31 August 2008.{{Cite web|title = The Whistler Sliding Centre and Whistler Olympic Park open to public tours.|publisher = VANOC|date = 5 June 2008|url = http://www.vancouver2010.com/olympic-news/n/news/the-whistler-sliding-centre-and-whistler-olympic-park-to-open-for-public-tours_36966sO.html|accessdate =6 June 2008}}{{Cite web|title = VANOC Board of Directors receives business plan update, endorses updated plans to engage public in the 2010 Winter Games.|publisher = VANOC|date = 21 May 2008|url = http://www.vancouver2010.com/olympic-news/n/news/vanoc-board-of-directors-receives-business-plan-update--endorses-updated-plans-to-engage-public-in-the-2010-winter-games_57908xD.html|accessdate =22 May 2008}} The cost to the public was 5 [[Canadian dollar]]s (C$5) with children under 12 admitted free. World Cup competition for bobsleigh and skeleton took place on 2–8 February 2009 while luge took place on 20–21 February 2009. The track was a finalist for the [[FIL World Luge Championships 2012|2012 FIL World Luge Championships]] along with [[Altenberg, Germany|Altenberg]], Germany, at the 2008 FIL Congress in [[Calgary, Alberta]], but the track withdrew its bid before the 28 June 2008 selection.{{Cite web|title = 56th FIL Congress in Calgary.|publisher = FIL|date = 29 April 2008|url = {{FIL-Luge link|url1 = http://www.fil-luge.org/News-Detail.155.0.html?&tx_ttnews|bracket1 = pS|url2 = =1207000800&tx_ttnews|bracket2 = pL|url3 = =2591999&tx_ttnews|bracket3 = arc|url4 = =1&tx_ttnews|bracket4 = tt_news|url5 = =3087&tx_ttnews|bracket5 = backPid|url6 = =157&cHash=d8838b66e6|bracket6 = |fil-lugelink = no|cite = yes}}|accessdate =1 May 2008}} {{Cite web|title = 56th FIL Congress in Calgary.|publisher = FIL|date = 28 June 2008|url = {{FIL-Luge link|url1 = http://www.fil-luge.org/News-Detail.155.0.html?&tx_ttnews|bracket1 = pS|url2 = =1212271200&tx_ttnews|bracket2 = pL|url3 = =2591999&tx_ttnews|bracket3 = arc|url4 = =1&tx_ttnews|bracket4 = tt_news|url5 = =3211&tx_ttnews|bracket5 = backPid|url6 = =157&cHash=211cbc0141|fil-lugelink = no|cite = yes}}|accessdate =29 June 2008}} During a 4–5 April 2009 weekend meeting of the FIL Commission at [[St. Leonhard]], Austria, it was recommended that the Centre be host for the [[FIL World Luge Championships 2013|2013 FIL World Luge Championships]].{{Cite web|title = Recommendations for 2013 World Championships in Whistler.|publisher = FIL|date = 8 April 2009|url = {{FIL-Luge link|url1 = http://www.fil-luge.org/News-Detail.155.0.html?&tx_ttnews|bracket1 = pS|url2 = =1238536800&tx_ttnews|bracket2 = pL|url3 = =2591999&tx_ttnews|bracket3 = arc|url4 = =1&tx_ttnews|bracket4 = tt_news|url5 = =10479&tx_ttnews|bracket5 = backPid|url6 = =157&cHash=bfb1f98fe1|fil-lugelink = no|cite = yes}}|accessdate =11 April 2009}} This was confirmed on 19–20 June 2009 at the 57th FIL Congress meeting in [[Liberec]], Czech Republic.{{Cite web|title = FIL Congress in Liberec.|publisher = FIL|date = 20 June 2009|url = {{FIL-Luge link|url1 = http://www.fil-luge.org/News-Detail.155.0.html?&tx_ttnews|bracket1 = pS|url2 = =1243807200&tx_ttnews|bracket2 = pL|url3 = =2591999&tx_ttnews|bracket3 = arc|url4 = =1&tx_ttnews|bracket4 = tt_news|url5 = =10655&tx_ttnews|bracket5 = backPid|url6 = =157&cHash=853d27fd14|fil-lugelink = no|cite = yes}}|accessdate =25 June 2009}} Post-Olympic usage is a responsibility of the Whistler 2010 Sports Legacies which operates the Sliding Centre, Whistler Olympic Park, and the [[Whistler Olympic and Paralympic Village]].{{Cite web|title = Whistler Legacy Society gets new identity.|publisher = Resort Municipality of Whistler|date = 9 February 2009|url = http://www.whistler.ca/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=691&Itemid=1|accessdate =5 April 2010}} The goal of this organization is to promote the legacy of the 2010 Winter Olympics and [[2010 Winter Paralympics]], promote healthy lifestyles and tourism in the British Columbia province, and offer revenue for the maintenance of the three facilities.{{Cite web|title = About Us.|publisher = Whistler 2010 Sports Legacies|url = http://www.whistler2010sportlegacies.com/about/tabid/169/language/en-CA/default.aspx|accessdate = 5 April 2010|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20100607220556/http://www.whistler2010sportlegacies.com/about/tabid/169/language/en-CA/Default.aspx#|archive-date = 7 June 2010|dead-url = yes|df = dmy-all}} ==Championships hosted== *[[2010 Winter Olympics]] *[[FIBT World Championships|IBSF World Bobsleigh and Skeleton Championships]]: [[IBSF World Championships 2019|2019]] *[[FIL World Luge Championships]]: [[FIL World Luge Championships 2013|2013]] *[[Bobsleigh World Cup]]: [[2008–09 Bobsleigh World Cup|2008–09]], [[2010–11 Bobsleigh World Cup|2010–11]], [[2011–12 Bobsleigh World Cup|2011–12]], [[2012–13 Bobsleigh World Cup|2012–13]], [[2015–16 Bobsleigh World Cup|2015–16]], [[2016–17 Bobsleigh World Cup|2016-17]] *[[Skeleton World Cup]]: [[2008–09 Skeleton World Cup|2008–09]], [[2010–11 Skeleton World Cup|2010–11]], [[2011–12 Skeleton World Cup|2011–12]], [[2012–13 Skeleton World Cup|2012–13]], [[2015–16 Skeleton World Cup|2015–16]], [[2016–17 Skeleton World Cup|2016–17]] *[[Luge World Cup]]: [[2008–09 Luge World Cup|2008–09]], [[2011–12 Luge World Cup|2011–12]], [[2013–14 Luge World Cup|2013–14]], [[2016–17 Luge World Cup|2016–17]] ==2010 Winter Olympics== ===Nodar Kumaritashvili=== {{main|Nodar Kumaritashvili}} On 12 February 2010, hours before the [[2010 Winter Olympics opening ceremony|opening ceremony for the 2010 Winter Olympics]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgian]] luger [[Nodar Kumaritashvili]] suffered a crash during a training run exiting out of turn 16.{{Cite news|title = Luge Crash at the Olympics|newspaper = New York Times|location =New York, NY|publisher = Arthur O. Sulzberger, Jr.|date = 12 February 2010| url = https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2010/02/12/sports/olympics/LUGEDEATH.html|accessdate =16 February 2010}} Kumaritashvili was injured when he flew off the track and collided with a steel pole.{{cite news|last = Branch|first = John|author2=Jonathan Abrams | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2010/02/13/sports/olympics/13luge.html?hp=&pagewanted=print | title = Luge Athlete's Death Casts Pall Over Games |work=New York Times | date = 12 February 2010 | accessdate =20 June 2010}}{{cite news|last = Bryant|first = Howard|author2=Bonnie D. Ford |url = http://sports.espn.go.com/olympics/winter/2010/news/story?id=4909034|title = Kumaritashvili killed in luge training| publisher = [[ESPN]]|date = 13 February 2010|accessdate =20 June 2010}} He was going {{convert|143.3|km/h|mph|abbr=on}} at the time of the crash. He died later that day from the injuries sustained in that crash.{{cite news|last = Bell|first = Terry|url=http://www.globaltvcalgary.com/story.html?id=2556532|title=Georgia's minister of sport pleads for a full investigation after luger's death|date=12 February 2010|publisher=Canwest News Service|accessdate=12 February 2010}} His accident came after other crashes during that week. This reignited concerns about the track's safety. Kumaritashvili was the first Olympic athlete to die at the Winter Olympics in training since [[1992 Winter Olympics|1992]] and the first luger to die in a practice event at the Winter Olympics since [[Kazimierz Kay-Skrzypeski]] of [[Great Britain at the 1964 Winter Olympics|Great Britain]] was killed at the [[Igls bobsleigh, luge, and skeleton track|luge track]] used for the [[1964 Winter Olympics]] in [[Innsbruck]].{{Citation|last = Wallechinsky|first = David|last2 = Loucky|first2 = Jaime|title = The Complete Book of the Winter Olympics: 2010 Edition|place = London|publisher = Aurum Press Limited|year = 2009|chapter = Luge (Toboggan): Men|page =158}} It was also luge's first fatality since 10 December 1975 when an Italian luger was killed.{{Cite web|title = Luge: Luge start moved as officials defend Whistler Sliding track.|publisher = VANOC|date = 13 February 2010|url = http://www.vancouver2010.com/olympic-news/n/news/afp-news/luge--luge-start-moved-as-officials-defend-whistler-sliding-track_274696sA.html|accessdate =13 February 2010}} A joint statement was issued by the FIL, the IOC, and VANOC over Kumaritashvili's death. Training was suspended for the rest of that day.{{Cite web|title = Joined Statement of IOC, FIL, and VANOC.|publisher = FIL|date = 12 February 2010|url = {{FIL-Luge link|url1 = http://www.fil-luge.org/News-Detail.335.0.html?&tx_ttnews|bracket1 = tt_news|url2 = =11561&tx_ttnews|bracket2 = backPid|url3 = =331&cHash=c1df2390c8|fil-lugelink = no|cite = yes}}| accessdate =13 February 2010}}{{Cite web|title = Joint VANOC-FIL Statement on Men's Luge Competition.|publisher = FIL|date = 13 February 2010|url = {{FIL-Luge link|url1 = http://www.fil-luge.org/News-Detail.335.0.html?&tx_ttnews|bracket1 = tt_news|url2 = =11565&tx_ttnews|bracket2 = backPid|url3 = =331&cHash=5acc6adb41|fil-lugelink = no|cite = yes}}|accessdate =13 February 2010}} According to the Coroners Service of British Columbia and the [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]], Kumaritashvili's death was an accident caused by a "convergence of several factors", including the high speed of the track, its technical difficulty, and the athlete's relative unfamiliarity with the track.{{citation |author = Tom Pawlowski |title = Coroner's Report into the Death of Kumaritashvili Nodar of Bakuriani, Georgia |url = http://www.pssg.gov.bc.ca/coroners/publications/docs/coroners-report-kumaritashvili-nodar.pdf |format = PDF |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/5tacmFWAh?url=http://www.pssg.gov.bc.ca/coroners/publications/docs/coroners-report-kumaritashvili-nodar.pdf |archivedate = 19 October 2010 |publisher = Ministry of Public Safety and Solicitor General, British Columbia |date = 16 September 2010 |accessdate = 19 October 2010 |deadurl = yes |df = }} As a preventive measure, an extra {{convert|100|ft|m|abbr=on}} of wall was added after the end of Turn 16, and the ice profile was changed. Also, the men's singles luge event start was moved from its start house to the one for both the women's singles and men's doubles event.{{Cite web|title = Joint VANOC – FIL Statement on Men’s Luge Competition|publisher = VANOC|date = 12 February 2010|url = http://www.vancouver2010.com/olympic-news/n/news/fil-statement-on-mens-luge-competition_274462nE.html|accessdate =12 February 2010 }} Women's singles and men's doubles start was moved to the Junior start house of the track, located after turn 5.{{Cite web |last = Herman|first = Martyn|title = Women sliders now have kids race – German.|publisher = Reuters|date = 14 February 2010|url = https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE61D2EQ20100214?feedType=RSS&feedName=everything&virtualBrandChannel=11563|accessdate =14 February 2010}}. Germany's [[Natalie Geisenberger]] complained that it was not a women's start but more of a ''Kinder'' ("children" in {{de icon}}) start. Her teammate Hüfner, who had the fastest speed on the two practice runs at {{convert|82.3|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}, stated that the new start position "does not help good starters like myself." American [[Erin Hamlin]], the [[FIL World Luge Championships 2009|2009 women's singles world champion]], stated the track was still demanding even after the distance was lessened from {{convert|1193|to|953|m|ft|abbr=on}} and one was still hitting {{convert|80|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}. During a 14 February 2010 interview with Reuters, FIL Secretary-General Svein Romstad stated that the federation considered cancelling the luge competition in the wake of Kumaritashvili's death two days earlier.{{Cite web|last = Reich|first = Sharon|title = FIL considered cancelling competition|publisher = Reuters|date = 15 February 2010|url = https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE61E11120100215?feedType=RSS&feedName=everything&virtualBrandChannel=11563|accessdate =16 February 2010}} Romstad stated that "[Kumaritashvili] ... made a mistake" on the crash though "any fatality is unacceptable". Additionally, Romstad stated that the start houses were moved to their current locations "mostly for an emotional reason". Because of Kumaritashvili's death, the FIL worked with the Sochi 2014 Olympic Organizing Committee to make the Russian National Sliding Centre in [[Rzhanaya Polyana]] slower in speed. Canada's [[Alex Gough (luger)|Alex Gough]] commented on 14 February (two days after Kumaritashvili's death) that "We’ve got the world championships here in a few years (2013) so hopefully we can actually have a race" instead of the start at the Junior start house.{{Cite web|last = Herman|first = Martyn|title = Huefner's power nap leads to a golden dream.|publisher = Reuters|date = 16 February 2010|url = https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE61G03I20100217?feedType=RSS&feedName=everything&virtualBrandChannel=11563|accessdate =17 February 2010}} On 18 February 2010, FIL President Fendt issued the following statement: {{quote|"At the conclusion of the luge competition at the Vancouver 2010 Olympic Games, our thoughts are with the family of Nodar Kumaritashvili. We again offer our heartfelt condolences to them, to his friends and to the entire Georgian Luge Federation. Nodar Kumaritashvili will forever stay in the hearts of all the members of the Luge family.
This has also been a difficult time for the Olympic athletes who competed in these Games. Their solidarity and sportsmanship was a tribute to the friend we lost. The International Luge Federation is touched by the outpouring of compassion and sympathy from people around the world. We will leave Whistler determined to do all we can to prevent a recurrence of this tragic event."{{Cite web|title = A statement from Josef Fendt, President of the International Luge Federation.|publisher = FIL|date = 18 February 2010|url = {{FIL-Luge link|url1 = http://www.fil-luge.org/News-Detail.335.0.html?&tx_ttnews|bracket1 = tt_news|url2 = =11593&tx_ttnews|bracket2 = backPid|url3 = =331&cHash=3ba51a96fe|fil-lugelink = no|cite = yes}}|accessdate =19 February 2010}}|}} Kumaritashvili was buried in his hometown of [[Bakuriani]], on 20 February 2010.{{Cite news|last = Metreveli|first = Irakli|title = Track controversy hangs over Georgian lugers [sic] funeral.|newspaper = Oregon Herald|location = Portland, Oregon|date = 20 February 2010|url = http://www.oregonherald.com/news/story/y/89218_track-controversy-hangs-over-georgian-lugers.htm|accessdate = 20 June 2010|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110720010324/http://www.oregonherald.com/news/story/y/89218_track-controversy-hangs-over-georgian-lugers.htm#|archive-date = 20 July 2011|dead-url = yes|df = dmy-all}} [[Georgian National Olympic Committee]] president Gia Natsvlishvili and Georgia president [[Mikheil Saakashvili]] raised concern and anger toward the Sliding Centre's organizers that the safety concerns were not addressed. ===Luge=== {{main|Luge at the 2010 Winter Olympics}} [[File:Tatjana Hüfner.jpg|thumb|alt=Athlete celebrating victory in event.|German luger Hüfner celebrating at the Sliding Centre following her gold in the women's singles event at the 2010 Winter Olympics on 16 February.]] On 11 February 2010, [[Romania at the 2010 Winter Olympics|Romania]]'s [[Violeta Strămăturaru]] was knocked unconscious after hitting several walls during a training run.{{Cite web|last = de Sorin|first = Anghel|title = Violeta Strămăturaru – out!|publisher = Jurnalul.ro|date = 12 February 2010|url = http://www.jurnalul.ro/stire-jurnalul/violeta-stramaturaru-out-535721.html|accessdate =20 June 2010|language=ro}} She was strapped to a backboard and placed on a stretcher though her arms were moving. Strămăturaru withdrew before the women's singles event. In the first run of the men's doubles luge competition on 17 February 2010, Austria's team of [[Tobias Schiegl]] and [[Markus Schiegl]] survived a crash on turn 16 where they came in at too high of an elevation. Tobias tried to correct the oversteer only to have the cousins collide on the opposite side of the ice wall, causing both to go airborne momentarily. Neither suffered any injury.{{Cite web|last = Herman|first = Martyn|title = Clinical Lingers time it right once again.|publisher = Reuters|date = 18 February 2010|url = https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE61H14B20100218?feedType=RSS&feedName=everything&virtualBrandChannel=11563|accessdate =20 June 2010}} [[Mihaela Chiras]] of Romania suffered the only crash of ten actual competitive runs (four men single, four women single, and two doubles), and that was during the second run of the women's singles event.{{Cite web|title = Sports Review of the 2010 Winter Olympic Games in Vancouver.|publisher = FIL|date = 19 February 2010|url = {{FIL-Luge link|url1 = http://www.fil-luge.org/News-Detail.335.0.html?&tx_ttnews|bracket1 = tt_news|url2 = =11597&tx_ttnews|bracket2 = backPid|url3 = =331&cHash=ba0d0db2e6|fil-lugelink = no|cite = yes}}|accessdate =20 February 2010}} Each of the five days of luge competition was attended by a sold-out crowd of 12,000 spectators. Event winners were Germany's Loch in men's singles,{{Cite web|title = 2010 Winter Olympics Luge men's singles official results.|publisher = FIL|date = 14 February 2010|url = http://www.fil-luge.org/filext/result_detail_select.asp?lan=en&currSeason=2009%2F2010&art=&cup_type=&event_id_fk=484|accessdate =1 April 2010}} Germany's Hüfner in women's singles,{{Cite web|title = 2010 Winter Olympics Luge women's singles official results.|publisher = FIL|date = 16 February 2010|url = http://www.fil-luge.org/filext/result_detail_select.asp?lan=en&currSeason=2009%2F2010&art=&cup_type=&event_id_fk=484|accessdate =1 April 2010}} and Austria's [[Andreas Linger|Andreas]] and [[Wolfgang Linger]] in doubles.{{Cite web|title = 2010 Winter Olympics Luge doubles official results.|publisher = FIL|date = 17 February 2010|url = http://www.fil-luge.org/filext/result_detail_select.asp?lan=en&currSeason=2009%0&art=&cup_type=&event_id_fk=484|accessdate =1 April 2010}} ===Skeleton=== {{main|Skeleton at the 2010 Winter Olympics}} [[File:Amy Williams.jpg|thumb|left|alt=Woman celebrating victory in sports competition.|2010 Winter Olympics women's skeleton gold medalist Amy Williams of Great Britain celebrating at the medal ceremony on 19 February 2010.]] The first [[Skeleton at the 2010 Winter Olympics|skeleton]] practice began down the full length of the track on 15 February 2010.{{Cite web|last = Herman|first = Martyn|title = Full fury of Whistler unleashed again|publisher = Reuters|date = 15 February 2010|url = https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE61F08520100216?feedType=RSS&feedName=everything&virtualBrandChannel=11563|accessdate =20 June 2010}} It was the first time that had been done since Kumaritashvili's death three days earlier. Britain's [[Shelley Rudman]] stated that "The IOC and VANOC have done all they can to make it a safe environment". Canada's [[Mellisa Hollingsworth]] had the fastest women's practice runs while her teammate Montgomery had the fastest men's practice runs. Montgomery and Hollingsworth also had the fastest practice times on both the 16th and the 17th.{{Cite web|title = Canadian Skeleton Team Tops Day Two Training.|publisher = FIBT|date = 17 February 2010|url = {{FIBT link|url1 = http://www.fibt.com/index.php?id=88&tx_ttnews|bracket1 = tt_news|url2 = =1296&tx_ttnews|bracket2 = backPid|url3 = =2&cHash=54fa8f2a96|fibtlink = no|cite = yes}}|accessdate =17 February 2010}}{{Cite web|title = Hollingsworth, Montgomery Solidify Favorite Status in Skeleton.|publisher = FIBT|date = 18 February 2010| url = {{FIBT link|url1 = http://www.fibt.com/index.php?id=88&tx_ttnews|bracket1 = tt_news|url2 = =1301&tx_ttnews|bracket2 = backPid|url3 = =2&cHash=0c828b8ab8|fibtlink = no|cite = yes}}|accessdate =18 February 2010}} No crashes occurred during the two days of skeleton competitions. Event winners were Montgomery in the men's and Britain's [[Amy Williams]] in the women's. ===Bobsleigh=== {{main|Bobsleigh at the 2010 Winter Olympics}} [[Bobsleigh at the 2010 Winter Olympics|Bobsleigh]] practice began on 17 February 2010 with the [[Bobsleigh at the 2010 Winter Olympics – Two-man|two-man]] event. Eight crashes among 57 runs took place that day.{{Cite web|title = Lange Among Leaders in 2-Man Bob Training.|publisher = FIBT|date = 18 February 2010|url = {{FIBT link|url1 = http://www.fibt.com/index.php?id=88&tx_ttnews|bracket1 = tt_news|url2 = =1316&tx_ttnews|bracket2 = backPid|url3 = =2&cHash=9071368f93|fibtlink = no|cite = yes}}|accessdate =18 February 2010}} Three crashes occurred during the two-man practice session on 18 February 2010.{{Cite web|title = Rush, Lange, Florshuetz Top 2-Man Training.|publisher = FIBT|date = 19 February 2010|url = {{FIBT link|url1 = http://www.fibt.com/index.php?id=88&tx_ttnews|bracket1 = tt_news|url2 = =1321&tx_ttnews|bracket2 = backPid|url3 = =2&cHash=e0b5ac003d|fibtlink = no|cite = yes}}| accessdate =19 February 2010}} Supplemental practice was offered on 19 February 2010 to both the [[Bobsleigh at the 2010 Winter Olympics – Two-woman|two-woman]] and [[Bobsleigh at the 2010 Winter Olympics – Four-man|four-man]] events out of caution, and further preparation for both events that took place the following week.{{Cite web|title = Supplementary Bobsleigh Training Offered in Whistler.|publisher = FIBT|date = 19 February 2010|url = {{FIBT link|url1 = http://www.fibt.com/index.php?id=88&tx_ttnews|bracket1 = tt_news|url2 = =1326&tx_ttnews|bracket2 = backPid|url3 = =2&cHash=50036f3ec3|fibtlink = no|cite = yes}}|accessdate =19 February 2010}} For the first run on 20 February 2010, a sled from [[Australia at the 2010 Winter Olympics|Australia]] crashed out and did not finish, while a sled from Great Britain was disqualified when the sled's brakeman was ejected during the first run.{{Cite web|title = Lange Takes Lead in Two-Man Bobsleigh.|publisher = FIBT|date = 21 February 2010|url = {{FIBT link|url1 = http://www.fibt.com/index.php?id=88&tx_ttnews|bracket1 = tt_news|url2 = =1406&tx_ttnews|bracket2 = backPid|url3 = =2&cHash=dcf2c00efc|fibtlink = no|cite = yes}}|accessdate =21 February 2010}} [[Liechtenstein at the 2010 Winter Olympics|Liechtenstein]]'s sled crashed out during the first run and finished, but did not start the second run. During the two-man event, runs three and four on 21 February 2010 were rescheduled to 16:00 [[Pacific Time Zone|PST]] (00:00 [[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]] on 22 February) for run three and 17:35 PST (01:35 UTC on the 22nd) for run four due to unseasonable warm weather.{{Cite web|title = Bobsleigh Schedule for Sunday Changed to 16:00.|publisher = FIBT|date = 21 February 2010|url = {{FIBT link|url1 = http://www.fibt.com/index.php?id=88&tx_ttnews|bracket1 = tt_news|url2 = =1401&tx_ttnews|bracket2 = backPid|url3 = =2&cHash=034b80705b|fibtlink = no|cite = yes}}|accessdate =21 February 2010}} Temperatures reached {{convert|10|C|F|abbr=on}} on the afternoon of the 20th and were expected to reach {{convert|12|C|F|abbr=on}} on the afternoon of the 21st. No crashes occurred in the final two runs of the event.{{Cite web|last = Withers|first = Tom|title = German driver Lange makes history with 4th gold.|publisher = Comcast.net|date = 22 February 2010|url = http://www.comcast.net/olympics/story.asp?i=20100222045017431427308&ref=rec&tm=&src=DOLY_BOB|accessdate =9 August 2010}} Germany's André Lange and [[Kevin Kuske]] won the two-man event. [[File:USA I in heat 1 of 2 man bobsleigh at 2010 Winter Olympics 2010-02-20.jpg|thumb|alt=Sled in action during a sports event.|Sixth-place USA-1 (Steven Holcomb driving) racing the track in the first heat of the bobsleigh two-man competition on 20 February 2010.]] Reactions from bobsledders about the track during the two-man event varied from exciting to anxious to dangerous.{{Cite web|last = Leicester|first = John|title = Speed of Olympics bobsled track is fast becoming a debate among competitors.|publisher = Cleveland.com|date = 21 February 2010|url = http://www.cleveland.com/olympics/index.ssf/2010/02/speed_of_olympics_bobsled_trac.html|accessdate =25 July 2010}} The [[Associated Press]] spoke to 13 of the 21 drivers who competed at the two-woman event on 23–24 February 2010 and the only one who did not feel safe on the track was [[Erin Pac]] of the United States. The three [[Germany at the 2010 Winter Olympics|German]] drivers who competed in the two-woman event stated through a team spokeswoman that they had no safety concerns about the track. [[File:Women's Bobsleigh Final.jpg|thumb|left|alt=Sled in action during a sports event at night.|Canada-1's gold medal team of Humphries (driving) and Moyse racing in the fourth run of bobsleigh two-woman event on 24 February 2010.]] Minor changes were made to the track on 22 February 2010 after bobsleigh four-man teams from [[Latvia at the 2010 Winter Olympics|Latvia]] and [[Croatia at the 2010 Winter Olympics|Croatia]] rolled over in supplementary practice.{{Cite web|last = Herman|first = Martyn|title = Whistler track tweaked after further spills.|publisher = Reuters|date = 22 February 2010|url = https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE61M0GT20100223?feedType=RSS&feedName=everything&virtualBrandChannel=11563|accessdate =20 June 2010}} Following a meeting with 11 team captains, practice runs were postponed by the FIBT until later that day to adjust the shape of turn 11 so it would be easier for sleds to get through the rest of the track without crashing. FIBT spokesman Don Krone also stated that it was common that turn profiles were changed when it was being used by other sliding disciplines such as luge and skeleton. After track alterations were done on 23 February 2010, the two fastest four-man practice times were done by Germany's Lange and the United States' [[Steven Holcomb]].{{Cite web|last = Herman|first = Martyn|title = Lange quickest in training as track mellows.|publisher = Reuters|date = 23 February 2010|url = https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSLDE61M2Q720100223?feedType=RSS&feedName=everything&virtualBrandChannel=11563|accessdate =20 June 2010}} Australia withdrew its four-man team on 23 February 2010 after two of its crew members suffered concussions from crashes sustained during track practice. Australia's [[chef de mission]] [[Ian Chesterman]] stated that the decision was not taken lightly and was done on the side of safety. [[File:USA-1 in heat 3 of 4 man bobsleigh at 2010 Winter Olympics 2010-02-27.jpg|thumb|alt=Sled starting run during a sports event.|United States-1's gold medal team (Front: Holcomb, Back (left to right): Mesler, Tomasevicz, and Olsen) starting the third run of the bobsleigh four-man event on 27 February 2010.]] In the two-woman event, defending [[FIBT World Championships 2009|world champion]] [[Nicole Minichiello]] of Britain had her sled flip over after turn 12 during the third run, but both Minichiello and her brakeman [[Gillian Cooke]] walked away from the crash.{{Cite web|title = Humphries and Moyse Take Women's Bob Gold.|publisher = FIBT|date = 25 February 2010|url = {{FIBT link|url1 = http://www.fibt.com/index.php?id=88&tx_ttnews|bracket1 = tt_news|url2 = =1461&tx_ttnews|bracket2 = backPid|url3 = =2&cHash=709e6cd1e0|fibtlink = no|cite = yes}}|accessdate =25 February 2010}} Minichiello and Cooke decided not to start the final run. In the final run, Russia-2's sled crashed which kept them at their finishing position of 18th. Meanwhile, the Germany-2 sled of [[Cathleen Martini]] and [[Romy Logsch]] was in fourth place after the third run, but was disqualified after Martini crashed in turn 13 of the final run, causing Logsch to be ejected from the sled. Both Martini and Logsch walked away from the crash by themselves.{{Cite web|last = Hendricks|first = Maggie|title = German bobsledding favorites in frightening crash.|publisher = Yahoo! Sports|date = 24 February 2010|url = https://sports.yahoo.com/olympics/vancouver/blog/fourth_place_medal/post/German-bobsledding-favorites-in-frightening-cras;_ylt=AhrtghYKH_ekx_Apkbf88299sbV_?urn=oly,223988|accessdate =25 February 2010}} Before this incident, Martini had never crashed before in her career. Canada's [[Kaillie Humphries]] and [[Heather Moyse]] won the event. Lange had the fastest practice times in the four-man event on the 24th with the final two practices taking place on the 25th.{{Cite web|title = Lange Among Top 4-Man Pilots in Training.|publisher = FIBT|date = 24 February 2010 | url = {{FIBT link|url1 = http://www.fibt.com/index.php?id=88&tx_ttnews|bracket1 = tt_news|url2 = =1451&tx_ttnews|bracket2 = backPid|url3 = =2&cHash=cf613e7c54|fibtlink = no|cite = yes}}|accessdate =25 February 2010}} For the four-man event's first two runs on 26 February, defending world champion Holcomb recorded the fastest track times in both runs while defending Olympic champion Lange had the fastest start times.{{Cite web|title = Holcomb Takes First Day 4-Man Lead.|publisher = FIBT|date = 27 February 2010|url = {{FIBT link|url1 = http://www.fibt.com/index.php?id=88&tx_ttnews|bracket1 = tt_news|url2 = =1481&tx_ttnews|bracket2 = backPid|url3 = =2&cHash=f3fe8a62e3|fibtlink = no|cite = yes}}|accessdate =27 February 2010}} Russia-2 driven by [[Alexandr Zubkov]], the defending four-man silver medalist and bronze medalist in the two-man event at these Games, crashed out in the first run when one of his steering ropes broke. Austria-1 and Slovakia-1 also crashed out in the first run, and neither sled started the second run with Russia-2. Second run crashes involved USA-2, Great Britain-1, and Japan-1. USA-2 did not start the third run. There were no crashes in the final two runs of the event.{{Cite web|title = 2010 Winter Olympics Bobsleigh four-man official results.|publisher = Fédération International de Bobsleigh et de Tobogganing (FIBT)|date = 27 February 2010|url = http://www.fibt.com/fileadmin/results/Vancouver%20Olympic%20Games/Feb%2027th%204Man%20Final%20Results.pdf|accessdate =28 February 2010}} America's team of Holcomb, [[Steve Mesler]], [[Curtis Tomasevicz]], and [[Justin Olsen]] won the event. ==Overall safety concerns== [[File:Jacques Rogge at news conference on death of Nodar Kumaritashvili 2010-02-12.jpg|thumb|alt=A man reacts with sorrow during an interview.|IOC President Jacques Rogge at a press conference following the death of Kumaritashvili at the Sliding Centre, on 12 February 2010.]] Kumaritashvili's death raised concerns about athlete safety at the Winter Olympics.{{Cite news|title = IOC to act on luge death tragedy.|agency=Associated Press|publisher = Olympics-NOW.com|date = 21 February 2010|url = http://www.olympics-now.com/2010/02/21/ioc-to-act-on-luge-death-tragedy/|accessdate =9 August 2010}} As of 21 February 2010, there were 30 crashes in bobsleigh and luge at the Sliding Centre. Debate was raised on tightening qualification standards in weeding out unqualified athletes, in requiring a large number of training runs, in slowing down the sliding tracks, or in combining the three. [[Sochi 2014 Olympic and Paralympic Organizing Committee| Organizers]] of the 2014 Winter Olympics said that the Russian National Sliding Centre was designed to be {{convert|6|to|9|km/h|mph|abbr=on}} slower than the Whistler Sliding Centre. Sochi's Sliding Centre was to be monitored via [[3-D computer graphics]] and [[computer simulation|simulation]]. The IOC has improved safety standards over the years such as lowering obstacles for the [[Equestrian at the Summer Olympics|equestrian]] three-day event, requiring protective head gear for [[Boxing at the Summer Olympics|boxing]] and [[Ice hockey at the Olympic Games|ice hockey]], and tightening qualification standards to preclude athletes not qualified for the event.{{Cite web| last = Withers| first = Tom| title = US bobsledder: Whistler track 'stupid fast'.| publisher = Yahoo! Sports| date = 20 February 2010| url = https://sports.yahoo.com/olympics/news?=txbobwomensbobsledrohb| accessdate =25 July 2010}} FIBT President Storey wanted to wait to review safety of bobsleigh, luge, and skeleton until after the 2010 Games, stating that track designers needed to find a balance between challenges and dangers on the track. Track designer Gurgel told ''[[Sport Bild]]'' that perhaps track walls should be raised {{convert|40|to|50|cm|in|abbr=on}} on future courses though a risk-proof course may not be possible. According to VANOC, over 30,000 runs were made prior to the games with neither the FIBT nor the FIL issuing public danger warnings about the track. IOC President [[Jacques Rogge]] stated that he "will do everything in my power that this should not happen again in the future". The FIL published their reports in regards to Kumaritashvili's death following the FIL Commissions Meeting in St. Leonhard, for both sport and technical commissions on 9–11 April 2010.{{Cite web|title = FIL Final Report to be published after the Commissions meetings.|publisher = FIL|date = 25 March 2010|url = {{FIL-Luge link|url1 = http://www.fil-luge.org/News-Detail.155.0.html?&tx_ttnews|bracket1 = tt_news|url2 = =11637&tx_ttnews|bracket2 = backPid|url3 = =307&cHash=7778c222d7|fil-lugelink = no|cite = yes}}|accessdate =27 March 2010}} This report was prepared by Romstad and Claire DelNegro, FIL Vice-President Sport Artificial Track. The 20-page report was released by the FIL to the IOC on 12 April 2010 and was released on FIL's website to the public on 19 April 2010.{{Cite web|title = Official Report to the International Olympic Committee on the accident of Georgia athlete Nodar Kumaritashvili at Whistler Sliding Center on February 12, 2010 during official luge training for the XXI. Winter Olympics Games|publisher = FIL|date = 12 April 2010|url = http://www.fil-luge.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Documents/Sonstiges/FIL_Final_Report.pdf|accessdate =19 April 2010}}{{Cite web|title = Publication on Monday: FIL submit reports to IOC.|publisher = FIL|date = 13 April 2010|url = {{FIL-Luge link|url1 = http://www.fil-luge.org/News-Detail.155.0.html?&tx_ttnews|bracket1 = tt_news|url2 = =11661&tx_ttnews|bracket2 = backPid|url3 = =45&cHash=e51ef3e6b3|fil-lugelink = no|cite = yes}}|accessdate =14 April 2010}}{{Cite web|title = FIL publishes Accident Report.|publisher = FIL|date = 19 April 2010|url = {{FIL-Luge link|url1 = http://www.fil-luge.org/News-Detail.155.0.html?&tx_ttnews|bracket1 = tt_news|url2 = =11671&tx_ttnews|bracket2 = backPid|url3 = =45&cHash=32aec05ba3|fil-lugelink = no|cite = yes}}|accessdate =19 April 2010}} Documents released in February 2011 showed that the speed of the course was a concern for several years before Kumaritashvili's death.[[Associated Press]], "Lugers' speed caused concern: e-mails", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 9 February 2011, p. 15. ==Track technical details== [[File:Whistler Sliding Centre-track map english.svg|thumb|left|alt=Map of a competition venue|The Whistler Sliding Centre track map]] ===Construction=== This venue was constructed on a [[First Nations]] designated site. According to the [[Squamish Nation|Squamish]], the area is referred to as a "Wild Spirit Place" or ''Kwekwayex Kwelh7aynexw'' while the [[Lillooet Tribal Council|Lil'oet]] call the area ''A7x7ulmecw'' or "Spirited Ground". It represents the beating of the [[Thunderbird (mythology)|Thunderbird]]'s huge wings filled with thunder in the air.{{Cite web|title = The Whistler Sliding Center official story.|publisher = The Whistler Sliding Centre|url = http://www.whistlerslidingcentre.com/Portals/1/THE_WSC_STORY.pdf|accessdate =10 December 2009}} Originally budgeted for C$55 million, the track's actual costs were C$105 million (€68 million). The track is made of {{convert|350|MT|LT ST|lk=on}} of reinforced concrete that was applied using pressurized spraying to reach a maximum thickness of {{convert|6|in|cm|abbr=on}}. Additionally, the track contains {{convert|12|km|mi|abbr=on}} of steel conduit, 600 [[awning]]s, and 700 lights. A total of 350 track footings were used to set the track on its proper foundation. Forty percent of those footings were completed by July 2006. There are over {{convert|100|km|mi|abbr=on}} of ammonia refrigeration piping used to keep the track frozen. Sloping and curves were contoured to within {{convert|1|to|3|mm|in|abbr=on}} of the planned design course. Ice thickness is {{convert|2|to|5|cm|in|abbr=on}} that is maintained by hand. There are 36 on-track [[video camera]]s and 42 "timing eyes" located at the Sliding Centre. The track also includes a control tower and administration buildings. There are two spectator overpasses (between turns 1 and 2, and turns 6 and 7) and three spectator underpasses (between turns 8 and 9, turns 11 and 12, and turns 15 and 16).{{Cite web|title = Street map leading to the Whistler Sliding Centre, including the track map itself.|publisher = VANOC|url = http://www.vancouver2010.com/olympic-spectator-guide/venues/the-whistler-sliding-centre/maps/big-wsc-street-map_148414hO.html|accessdate =17 December 2009}} It seated 11,650 spectators during the 2010 Games. ===Sustainability=== To promote sustainability, the site was selected directly adjacent to an already used part of a major ski area. It was also designed to minimize vegetation and the [[ecological footprint]] in the area. For energy efficiency, trees were retained to cast shade with weather protection and a shading system used to cover parts of the track. The track itself is painted white to maintain low temperatures while minimizing energy demand on the refrigeration system. Waste heat from the refrigeration plant is captured and reused to heat buildings on-site, and could provide other heat uses in the future. Any wood waste created from site clearing activities during venue construction was [[compost]]ed for reuse. Other on-site buildings also followed similar green building design principles.{{Cite web|title = Sustainability and legacy information on the site selection area for the Whistler Sliding Centre.|publisher = VANOC|url = http://www.vancouver2010.com/olympic-spectator-guide/venues/the-whistler-sliding-centre/sustainability---legacy/|accessdate =10 December 2009}} ===Awards=== In 2008, the Sliding Centre received two British Columbia Ready-Mixed Concrete Association Awards for Excellence in Concrete Construction. The first award was for Public Works while the second one was for the Century Award.{{Cite web|title = 2008 BC Awards for Excellence in Concrete Construction, including the Whistler Sliding Centre.|publisher = British Columbia Ready-Mixed Concrete Association|url = http://www.bcrmca.bc.ca/media/2008%20winners.pdf|accessdate = 10 December 2009|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110706165056/http://www.bcrmca.bc.ca/media/2008%20winners.pdf#|archive-date = 6 July 2011|dead-url = yes|df = dmy-all}} On 22 August 2006, VANOC targeted Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design Canada by applying for "silver" green building certification for the {{convert|708|m2|sqft|abbr=on}} refrigeration plant building. The refrigeration plant received "gold" certification level on 2 February 2010.{{Cite web|title = The Whistler Sliding Centre Refrigeration Building.|publisher = Canada Green Building Council|url = http://www.cagbc.org/leed/leed_projects/registered_projects/building_registrations10381.php?project_city=Whistler&project_province=BC|accessdate =28 March 2010}} ===Characteristics=== {| class="wikitable" |+ Physical data{{Cite web|title = Facts and Figures|publisher = Whistler Sliding Centre|url = http://whistlerslidingcentre.com/venue/facts/tabid/105/language/en-CA/default.aspx|accessdate = 3 July 2008|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20111004123201/http://whistlerslidingcentre.com/venue/facts/tabid/105/language/en-CA/default.aspx#|archive-date = 4 October 2011|dead-url = yes|df = dmy-all}} ! Sport ! Length ! Turns ! Vertical drop (start to finish) ! Average grade (%) |- |Bobsleigh and skeleton |{{convert|1450|m|ft|abbr=on}} |16 |{{convert|152|m|ft|abbr=on}} |10.5 |- |Luge – men's singles |{{convert|1374|m|ft|abbr=on}} |16 |Not listed |Not listed |- |Luge – women's singles and doubles |{{convert|1193|m|ft|abbr=on}} |14 |Not listed |Not listed |- |Junior (bobsleigh, skeleton, luge) |{{convert|953|m|ft|abbr=on}} |11 |Not listed |Not listed |} {| class="wikitable" |+Turns ! Turn ! Name ! Origin of the name ! {{Tooltip|Ref|Reference(s)}} |- |1 |Slingshot |For the [[slingshot]] effect of the turn after the start of the bobsleigh, skeleton, or men's single's luge run. |{{Cite news|last = Ogilive|first = Clare|title = Speedy sliding track gets a few nicknames|newspaper = The Province|location = Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada|publisher = Canwest Publishing|date = 18 February 2009|url = https://theprovince.com/health/family-child/Speedy+sliding+track+getting+nicknames/1302859/story.html|accessdate =20 June 2010}} |- |2 |Fallaway |For the steep drop of the track after this curve. It has a 20% [[grade (slope)|grade]], the steepest part of the track. | |- |3 |Wedge |Where the doubles and women's single luge sleds coming from the start house "wedge" themselves onto the track. |{{Cite news|title = Whistler Sliding Centre Facts|newspaper = [[USA Today]]|location = [[McLean, Virginia]]|publisher = [[Gannett Company]]|url = https://www.usatoday.com/sports/olympics/vancouver/sliding/whistler-sliding-graphic.htm|accessdate =7 February 2010 | date=3 February 2010}} |- |7 |Lueders Loop |After Canadian bobsledder [[Pierre Lueders]], who crashed out at the curve during track certification in March 2008. | |- |9, 10 |Lynx |After the large population of [[lynx]] located in the British Columbia province. Also to the turn's being shaped like the head of the lynx if the track map is viewed from the air. |{{Cite web|last = Hatler|first = David F.|author2=Alison M. M. Beal |title = Furbearer management guidelines: Lynx (''Lynx canadenis'').|publisher = Habitat Conservation Trust Fund|year = 2003|url = http://www.llbc.leg.bc.ca/public/pubdocs/bcdocs/378286/lynx.pdf|accessdate =7 February 2010}} |- |11 |Shiver |After the turn "sending shivers down an athlete's spine" prior to entry into the next four corners of the track. | |- |12, 13, 14, 15 |{{Nowrap|[[Gold Rush]] Trail}} |Labyrinth of four curves without a straightaway. Named because a mistake on this part of the track could cost competitors a chance at a gold medal. It is also in reference to the [[British Columbia gold rushes]] that happened between 1850 and 1899. Turn 13 of the Gold Rush Trail was christened "50/50" by American bobsledder Holcomb during the first day of four-man training in February 2009. 50% of the sleds crashed on Turn 13 on their runs that day. The next day, Holcomb posted the name on the wall of that turn, which the track manager approved. Holcomb's crew was also the first to go down the track that next day, successfully completing the run. The name stuck, being used in broadcast coverage of the [[Vancouver Olympics]]. Following Holcomb's death in 2017, turn 13 had his emblem (similar to [[Superman]]) embedded at the turn during the [[2017-18 Bobsleigh World Cup|2017-18 bobsleigh]], [[2017-18 Luge World Cup|luge]], and [[2017-18 Skeleton World Cup|skeleton World Cup season]]. | |- |16. |Thunderbird |After the Thunderbird who is prevalent in much of [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native culture]] in [[Aboriginal peoples in Canada|British Columbia]]. It represents the thunder in the air after a competitor finishes the track and is also its final curve. | |} Turn names for 4–6 and 8 were not given. Track [[g-forces]] were expected to reach up to 5.02 for men's singles luge. Maximum speed was reached at {{convert|147.9|km/h|mph|abbr=on}} in four-man bobsleigh during the certification process. ==Track records== The luge track records shown were set at the men's singles start house and women's singles/men's doubles start houses during the World Cup competition in February 2009. After Kumaritashvili's death on 12 February 2010, the competition for men's singles was moved to the women's singles/men's doubles start house while the competition for women's singles/ men's doubles was moved to the junior start house. The fastest runs set during the 2010 Winter Olympics are not on this list until an issue between the Whistler 2010 Sports Legacies and the FIL is resolved. {| class="wikitable" |+Track records !
